id: Kiwibank business insights: The commercial advantage of sustainability-level 8/20 Customhouse Quay, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Kiwibank business insights: The commercial advantage of sustainability
venue: level 8/20 Customhouse Quay, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
“ 60% of consumers are now actively investing time and money in brands that do good, while nearly half have dropped products over environmental impact” (Kantar Better Futures 2025) 
Discover how sustainability can drive profits, reduce costs, and open new markets.
In today’s economic climate, businesses are under more pressure than ever to cut costs, stay competitive, and grow revenue. The good news? Embracing sustainability can help you do just that.
Co-hosted by Kiwibank, WellingtonNZ and the Sustainable Business Network (SBN). At this practical and business-focused event you’ll learn how smart sustainability strategies can help your business thrive. From reducing energy bills by electrifying your operations, to winning new customers by reporting on your emissions, sustainability is no longer just the right thing to do; it’s a commercial advantage.
What to expect:
Insights from the Sustainable Business Network on the real, bottom-line benefits of sustainability
A keynote from Mike Casey, Founder of Rewiring Aotearoa, on how electrification is helping Kiwi businesses cut costs and future-proof against rising energy prices
Real-world examples and tips you can apply now
The opportunity to connect with other business leaders tackling the same challenges
About the hosts
At Kiwibank, we're proud to be B-Corp certified, joining a global movement of businesses committed to balancing purpose and profit. Sustainability is core to how we operate—from reducing our own carbon footprint to helping Kiwi businesses fund their low-emissions future. We’re investing $2 billion in sustainable finance by 2030 and offering tools to help our customers track and cut their emissions. As a purpose-led bank, we’re here to back businesses that are building a better Aotearoa.
WellingtonNZ is the Economic Development Agency for the Wellington region, supporting businesses to grow, innovate and thrive. WellingtonNZ is committed to building a sustainable region - supporting initiatives that protect the wellbeing of the people and environment, both now and in the future. 
SBN supports a network of more than 400 organisations working towards a future where people and nature thrive.

id: Wellington Leadership Group: Leading from Within: Servant Leadership Through the Lens of PTSD Recovery-40 Mercer Street, City, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Wellington Leadership Group: Leading from Within: Servant Leadership Through the Lens of PTSD Recovery
venue: 40 Mercer Street, City, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Nick Tomlin’s talk, Leading from Within: Servant Leadership Through the Lens of PTSD Recovery, shares a powerful account of how living with PTSD has deepened his understanding and practice of Servant Leadership. By weaving personal experience with leadership insight, he illustrates how vulnerability, empathy, and resilience are not signs of weakness, but powerful tools for healing and leading authentically.
The session encourages leaders to embrace authenticity, support mental well-being, and foster cultures rooted in trust and service. Key points include:
Understanding Servant Leadership and how it differs from traditional authority-driven models
Harnessing vulnerability to build trust and psychological safety within teams
Sustaining resilience while navigating personal and professional adversity
Creating supportive cultures where mental health is valued and people can thrive as their full selves
It’s a compelling reminder that leadership is not about having all the answers—it’s about leading with heart, especially through the hard chapters.
About Nick Tomlin
Born in Kent, England in 1968, [Name] served 25 years across the British Army and Royal Air Force, rising from Combat Medical Technician to Special Forces Commander of the Light Surgical Group. His deployments took him from Northern Ireland to Afghanistan, and he also proudly represented his service in rugby, cricket, and Ironman events.
Following retirement, he became Medical Manager for the London 2012 Olympics before emigrating with his family to New Zealand. Today, he channels his energy into resilience coaching and mental health advocacy, drawing on personal experience after a post-service diagnosis of PTSD.
With gratitude for the support of his wife Fay, their two sons, and the SPARTA Project, he now speaks openly about invisible wounds, the power of vulnerability, and his mission to help others find hope and healing—proving that true strength lies not in silence, but in connection.
About Results Coaching
Founded in 2011, Results Coaching (formerly Setanta Consulting), is one of New Zealand’s fastest growing coaching practices. Our promise is to expand the horizons of our clients measured by observable growth through coaching and training events. As one participant put it, “This is the type of talk I’m looking for at my stage of my career, i.e. focuses on personal development rather than technical skills.”
Please Note: We may photograph or record the event for promotion purposes and may reproduce the image of any person who attends for any purpose without payment.

id: CPD: Mastering Masterspec Specifications WELLINGTON | ⭐ 20 CPD Points-10 Dunlop Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: CPD: Mastering Masterspec Specifications WELLINGTON | ⭐ 20 CPD Points
venue: 10 Dunlop Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
⭐ CPD Points: 20
Description
This CPD course, titled "Mastering Masterspec Specifications," is designed to provide specifiers with comprehensive training on effectively utilising the Masterspec platform for specification writing. Participants will learn the ins and outs of navigating the Masterspec platform, setting up their specifications, managing user accounts, and optimising the use of various features such as Office Masters, MasterKey, and mDocs. The course covers essential topics ranging from basic specification setup to advanced specification management techniques, ensuring participants gain practical skills to streamline their specification writing process.
Designed by specifiers for specifiers
This course is designed for specifiers, including architects, designers, engineers, and other professionals involved in the construction industry, who are responsible for creating specifications for building projects. Whether you are new to the Masterspec platform or looking to enhance your proficiency in specification writing, this course provides valuable insights and practical skills to optimise your workflow and maximise the benefits of using Masterspec for specification management.
Why should specifiers take this course
Specifiers should take this course to enhance their proficiency in specification writing and maximise the benefits offered by the Masterspec platform. By mastering the tools and functionalities covered in this course, specifiers can:
Improve Efficiency: Learn how to navigate the Masterspec website and utilise its features effectively, saving time and effort in specification writing tasks.
Ensure Accuracy: Gain insights into best practices for setting up specifications, assigning roles, and managing user accounts to maintain data accuracy and consistency.
Enhance Collaboration: Understand how to collaborate with team members, assign roles, and share specifications seamlessly within the organization, promoting teamwork and productivity.
Stay Updated: Stay abreast of the latest features and updates on the Masterspec platform, ensuring specifiers are equipped with the knowledge to leverage new tools for enhanced specification writing.
Optimise Workflow: Discover advanced techniques for managing specifications, utilising Office Masters, and integrating with drawing sets using MasterKey, leading to streamlined workflow and project efficiency.
Ensure Compliance: Learn about NZCIC guidelines and best practices for adding, editing, and exporting guidelines to ensure compliance with industry standards and regulations.
Boost Professional Development: Acquire valuable skills and knowledge that contribute to professional growth and advancement in the field of specification writing, enhancing career prospects and opportunities.

id: NZ Species Edit-a-thon 2025-150 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: NZ Species Edit-a-thon 2025
venue: 150 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
As the internet is increasingly taken over by sponsored posts and AI-generated content, Wikipedia remains steadfast as a source of verifiable, up-to-date information. It’s one of the most visited websites in the world, maintained by around 120,000 volunteer editors across the globe, and it could use your help.
Over two Saturdays in August, we’re running Wikipedia edit-a-thons to create and improve articles focused on Aotearoa New Zealand's unique native flora and fauna. All are welcome – whether you’re a complete newbie or have experience editing – take this opportunity to develop your skills while contributing to the world's most comprehensive encyclopedia.
Anyone can edit Wikipedia, and you’ll be guided by highly experienced editors along the way. We'll provide all the training and resources you need to get started, and the native vegetation of Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush will provide the perfect location for collaborating with fellow nature enthusiasts to share our unique biodiversity with the world.
Bring a laptop and charger – all other resources are provided.
Whether you want to come along for just one day, or book in for both, we’re looking forward to having you join us.
Dates: Saturday 2nd August 2025 and Saturday 9th August 2025
Time: 10:00–16:00 NZST
Location: Ōtari-Wilton's Bush, Wellington, New Zealand. We will be located in the Leonard Cockayne Centre.
Getting to Ōtari: Take the No 14 bus from the city centre to Gloucester Street, which is just outside Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. You can also come by car and park in the main public car park on Wilton Road or along Churchill Drive. More information at this link.
Tickets are $5NZD which includes morning tea, lunch and afternoon tea. Places are limited.
Further information is available on the event pages for August 2 and August 9.

id: Next-Level BA: half-day workshop (Wellington)-2/318 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Next-Level BA: half-day workshop (Wellington)
venue: 2/318 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Next-Level BA: How to maximise your value-add
A half-day workshop for Business Analysts looking to take things to the next level.
What this course isn't...
This isn't about your traditional 'BA' skills - we won't be learning to write better requirements, user stories, or processes!
What this course is...
This is a course focused on a mindset shift (with the tools to back it up) to enable you to add more value as a BA. As projects become more ambiguous and agile, the expectations on a BA are changing in a way gives us the opportunity to make a bigger impact - if we have the skills to take advantage...
Workshop scope:
0. Intro / ‘Next-Level BA’ definition
Learn what makes a “Next-Level BA” – someone who jumps into projects early, stays focused on outcomes, regularly steps back to see the bigger picture, acts with purpose, and takes the initiative to lead. This introduction pushes BAs to move beyond the limiting “I’m just a BA” mindset and embrace a more proactive approach that doesn’t require formal authority to make an impact.
1. The evolving role of a BA
See how the BA role has changed from working on clearly defined, waterfall projects to handling small, ambiguous initiatives with constant change. We’ll look at how design now happens alongside build, how BAs wear multiple hats, and why organisations need BAs to be leaders who can handle uncertainty rather than just task-executors. Understand the difference between working “in” versus “on” a project to maximise your value.
2. Setting up good decision-making in a project
Develop ways to establish what success looks like from day one of any project. This practical framework drives better outcomes by creating alignment, building trust, and enabling smarter decisions throughout the project. You’ll create your own set of ready-to-use success criteria that you can bring out in workshops to guide projects toward meaningful outcomes rather than just outputs.
3. Defining the pathway for problem solving
Get to grips with “definedness” – understanding where your project sits on the spectrum from well-defined to highly undefined problems. Build a playbook for tackling different types of problems, knowing when to use existing approaches, when to adapt them, and when to create new ones. This thoughtful approach buys you time while you learn more about complex problems and increases your chances of success.
4. Ensuring the right things are being worked on
Go beyond “I delivered what I was asked to” and make sure you’re not just doing things right, but doing the right things. Create a practical checklist to assess whether initiatives will truly add value, address root problems, and align with what the business can actually implement. Learn to question scope consistently and push back when necessary to avoid wasting time on projects that won’t deliver real benefits.
5. Risk tolerance / ensuring you are adding value
Find the sweet spot between risk and cost by knowing when you’ve gathered enough information to proceed. Avoid analysis paralysis by tailoring your approach based on who will be affected, what systems are involved, how easily changes can be reversed, and your organisation’s history with similar work. Design approaches that reduce the impact of mistakes, allowing for faster, more cost-effective decision-making.
6. ‘Selling’ in the decision-making process
Build a clear approach to influencing decisions through effective storytelling. Learn to establish the need for change, reinforce what success looks like, address potential barriers upfront, present your solution convincingly, and provide a clear path forward. Create decision-maker profiles to help customise your approach to different stakeholders based on whether they focus more on the journey or destination, respond to emotion or logic, and other key characteristics.
7. Other potential stumbling blocks (plus how to look after yourself!)
Understand that projects don’t exist in isolation – organisational culture, maturity, history, and competing priorities all affect your ability to deliver. Learn to assess these factors systematically and adjust your approach accordingly. Recognise your circles of influence and control to protect yourself from burnout when facing organisational barriers that can’t be changed, accepting that some challenges simply can’t be overcome!
8. Recap
Bring together all aspects of being a Next-Level BA, committing to consciously developing and applying these skills in your work. Remember that while these concepts aren’t complicated, deliberately putting them into practice will significantly improve your effectiveness and impact as a BA.
Who's the workshop for?
This course is designed for experienced Business Analysts. If you are used to working ‘in’ projects but are ready to take more control in shaping them, then this is the perfect course for you!
What will you get out of the course?
You will walk out of this workshop with some genuinely practical skills to help put you in a leadership position within a project environment (shaping the approach, and course that the project takes). 
Course structure
The course will run 1:00 – 5:00 with afternoon tea provided.
Venue
Venue is Urban Hub - Level 4 (Kent) meeting room.

id: Fur Real: Mastering the New Pet Rules for Stronger Tenancy Outcomes [Wellington]-Level 1/60 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Fur Real: Mastering the New Pet Rules for Stronger Tenancy Outcomes [Wellington]
venue: Level 1/60 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
A 3.5-hour strategic training for landlords and property managers
The law has changed.
The right to keep pets at rentals is no longer up for debate—it's here, and it’s coming into effect soon.
For landlords and property managers, that means one thing: it’s time to stop burying your head in the sand. The sooner you understand the new rules, adapt your strategy, and adjust your systems, the better your outcomes will be.
Join tenancy expert Sarina Gibbon for this dynamic and practical 3.5-hour workshop designed to give you clarity, control, and commercial confidence under the new pet tenancy laws. You’ll walk away knowing exactly how to protect your property, vet tenants and pets properly, draft enforceable clauses, and maximise business continuity—all while staying compliant.
🔑 What You’ll Learn:
What the new presumptive pet rights really mean for you
How to strategically structure tenancy agreements with fair and enforceable pet clauses
What reasonable grounds for refusing a pet look like in practice
What you can legally ask about a pet during the application process
How to vet pet-owning tenants and manage risk with confidence
The roles of pet bonds, landlord insurance, and the Tenancy Tribunal
How to balance your legal obligations with business expediency and long-term tenancy success

🧠 Workshop Includes:
✔ 3.5 hours of expert-led training
✔ Light morning tea
✔ Real-life scenarios and interactive activities
✔ Guest insights from insurance and proptech professionals
✔ Take-home clause templates, checklists, and Tribunal-prep tools

👩‍🏫 About Your Trainer
Sarina Gibbon is the Director of Tenancy Advisory Ltd, a boutique consultancy specialising in residential tenancy strategy. With a reputation as one of New Zealand’s most trusted tenancy experts, Sarina brings 15+ years of experience helping landlords, property managers, tenants, and community housing providers not just meet legal standards—but exceed them. Her training is known for being sharp, practical, and deeply focused on maximising outcomes and minimising stress.


🐾 Proudly Supported by Renti
We're thrilled to welcome Renti as our official content and marketing partner for the Fur Real workshop series! Renti will be joining us in person across all four locations to present practical, tech-powered strategies for navigating the new pet rules with ease. Attendees will also receive:
✅ A 3-month subscription waiver for agencies who sign up at the event
✅ Early access to Renti Academy and a one-month cancellation policy for trial sign-ups
✅ Bonus prize giveaways at each session
Renti’s smart tenancy tools are the perfect complement to the new pet provisions—come see them in action!
🐾 With Expert Support from Initio Insurance
We’re proud to partner with Initio, a leader in landlord insurance, to bring you expert guidance on navigating the insurance implications of pets in rentals. While Initio won’t be attending in person, they’re contributing:
📘 A free downloadable eBook on pet-related damage and insurance coverage
🎥 A BONUS video Q&A session answering common insurance questions
📋 A co-branded post-event checklist on pet-proofing your rental and protecting your investment
These resources will be made available exclusively to ticket holders—ensuring you walk away with long-term tools and practical know-how.

🎟️ Tickets
Discounted Early Bird Tickets On Sale Until 31 July 
Spaces are limited. Book early to secure your spot. 
✈️  Nationwide Training Sessions 
Not in Wellington? Sign up to our other sessions at Auckland, Christchurch or Dunedin.

id: Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Christchurch-456 Papanui Road, Christchurch-Humanitix
name: Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Christchurch
venue: 456 Papanui Road, Christchurch
description:
We're pleased to invite you to join us for this workshop on Building resilience and unlocking the power of the mind.
Why this matters:
In our rapidly changing world, resilience emerges as a fundamental skill. It's not just about bouncing back from adversity but confidently navigating change. Resilience enables individuals to navigate uncertainty with confidence and adaptability. This 90-minute workshop delves into the profound significance of resilience, offering participants practical insights and actionable strategies to cultivate resilience and harness the potential of the mind. By equipping individuals with these tools, the workshop empowers them to not only weather storms but also thrive in dynamic environments.
What to expect:
During this interactive workshop, participants will explore the core concepts of resilience and the mind-body connection through engaging discussions, experiential exercises, and practical demonstrations. They will learn evidence-based techniques to enhance their resilience, manage stress effectively, and cultivate a positive mindset amidst adversity. By the end of the session, attendees will emerge with a comprehensive toolkit to fortify their mental resilience and embrace change with confidence.
Who this is for:
This workshop caters to individuals across all organisational levels who are eager to enhance their resilience and cultivate a resilient mindset. Whether you're an owner, manager, chef, senior staff member, or junior employee, this workshop offers invaluable insights and practical strategies to bolster resilience and thrive in today's fast-paced world.
About the presenter, Sarah Robb
Sarah is a certified coach, counselor, and Master Practitioner of NLP (neuro-linguistic programming) holding a Bachelor's degree in Psychology.
With a passion for transformation, she guides individuals through retraining their brains and breaking free from limiting beliefs and patterns. Drawing on her extensive lived experience, Sarah has collaborated with over 200 clients and organisations, empowering them to apply practical tools and strategies for significant improvements in their mental health.
Sarah is motivated to continue creating positive change and to educate people about the power of the mind and how to use life's challenges as an opportunity for growth.

id: The Big Bad World of Cyber Why SMEs Need to Stay on Guard-Otaihanga Road, Paraparaumu, Kāpiti Coast 5036-Humanitix
name: The Big Bad World of Cyber Why SMEs Need to Stay on Guard
venue: Otaihanga Road, Paraparaumu, Kāpiti Coast 5036
description:
The Big Bad World of Cyber
Why SMEs Need to Stay on Guard
Electra Business Breakfast – B2B networking – Sponsored by Electra – Supported by Business Kāpiti
Nau mai haere mai Electra Business Breakfast is pleased to welcome Jan Thornborough, Founder of Outfox Ltd who trained with the best at New Zealand's National Cyber Security Centre and now helps SMEs navigate the risks of the digital world.  Cyber threats aren’t just a big business problem – small businesses are prime targets too.
In this practical, no-jargon session, Jan will break down what’s really happening in cybercrime, why it matters to your business, and simple steps to stay secure.  Expect real stories, useful insights, and advice you can act on – because staying cyber-safe is simply just smart business these days.
Attend this Breakfast and stay one step ahead of cybercrime.  Outfox understand that a cyber-attack can destroy people’s lives.  They believe that people deserve to feel safe and secure in the knowledge that their organisation is protected.  Jan and team love outfoxing the bad guys and empowering small business to be cyber resilient in their journey of growth.
See you there! Book early to avoid disappointment!
WELLNESS UPDATE
Please don’t attend if you are feeling unwell.  We look forward to seeing you all soon.
------------------------------------------------
ABOUT THE SPEAKER:
Jan Thornborough
Founder & Director, Outfox Ltd
Prior to setting up her own business, Jan was head of the Cyber Resilience Unit at New Zealand’s National Cyber Security Centre, helping nationally significant organisations become more cyber resilient. 
She founded Outfox in 2021 (under its original name of Intelligensia) after realising that although big organisations were dealing with cyber risks, small and medium-sized businesses and not-for-profit organisations were being left behind. 
She helps small businesses make smarter cyber decisions and build their confidence to operate in a risky digital world.  She believes your business deserves better than ‘hope for the best’ cybersecurity.
Electra Business Breakfast is an independent networking programme that seeks to INSPIRE, CONNECT and ENGAGE where everyone is welcome.

id: CPD: Mastering Masterspec Specifications PARAPARAUMU | ⭐ 20 CPD Points-Otaihanga Road, Otaihanga 5036, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: CPD: Mastering Masterspec Specifications PARAPARAUMU | ⭐ 20 CPD Points
venue: Otaihanga Road, Otaihanga 5036, New Zealand
description:
⭐ CPD Points: 20
Description
This CPD course, titled "Mastering Masterspec Specifications," is designed to provide specifiers with comprehensive training on effectively utilising the Masterspec platform for specification writing. Participants will learn the ins and outs of navigating the Masterspec platform, setting up their specifications, managing user accounts, and optimising the use of various features such as Office Masters, MasterKey, and mDocs. The course covers essential topics ranging from basic specification setup to advanced specification management techniques, ensuring participants gain practical skills to streamline their specification writing process.
Designed by specifiers for specifiers
This course is designed for specifiers, including architects, designers, engineers, and other professionals involved in the construction industry, who are responsible for creating specifications for building projects. Whether you are new to the Masterspec platform or looking to enhance your proficiency in specification writing, this course provides valuable insights and practical skills to optimise your workflow and maximise the benefits of using Masterspec for specification management.
Why should specifiers take this course
Specifiers should take this course to enhance their proficiency in specification writing and maximise the benefits offered by the Masterspec platform. By mastering the tools and functionalities covered in this course, specifiers can:
Improve Efficiency: Learn how to navigate the Masterspec website and utilise its features effectively, saving time and effort in specification writing tasks.
Ensure Accuracy: Gain insights into best practices for setting up specifications, assigning roles, and managing user accounts to maintain data accuracy and consistency.
Enhance Collaboration: Understand how to collaborate with team members, assign roles, and share specifications seamlessly within the organization, promoting teamwork and productivity.
Stay Updated: Stay abreast of the latest features and updates on the Masterspec platform, ensuring specifiers are equipped with the knowledge to leverage new tools for enhanced specification writing.
Optimise Workflow: Discover advanced techniques for managing specifications, utilising Office Masters, and integrating with drawing sets using MasterKey, leading to streamlined workflow and project efficiency.
Ensure Compliance: Learn about NZCIC guidelines and best practices for adding, editing, and exporting guidelines to ensure compliance with industry standards and regulations.
Boost Professional Development: Acquire valuable skills and knowledge that contribute to professional growth and advancement in the field of specification writing, enhancing career prospects and opportunities.

id: Work Smarter Horowhenua. Everyday AI for Everyday Businesses-102 Liverpool Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Work Smarter Horowhenua. Everyday AI for Everyday Businesses
venue: 102 Liverpool Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand
description:
We're sold out! If you're interested in attending this event and would like to be on the wait list, please contact us at info@littleandloud.co.nz.
We’re living in a world where AI adoption is outpacing AI literacy.

Global research shows that three in four employees say they’re using some form of AI at work.
Of these, over 50% say that they hide their AI use on important tasks, and up to 80% say that they are bringing their own AI to work.
More people are using AI, without understanding how it works, without telling their employers that they are using it, without considering the implications, and without knowing how to get the most from the tools they’re using.
This is where AI literacy becomes essential - it’s not just knowing how to use AI tools, it’s about understanding what’s possible, and knowing you don’t need to be technically savvy to use it well.
This practical two-hour in-person workshop is for real people in real businesses; who want to use AI to do more with the resources and tools they already have.
You’ll learn:
What AI actually is, where it’s heading, and why it matters for every kind of business
The best tools for things like admin, planning, performance, content, customer service, and strategy – and what to avoid
How to use AI responsibly: the risks, red flags, and how to keep it ethical
How to “train” AI to sound like you and reflect your business, not bland templates
Step-by-step ways to save yourself hours each week, without sacrificing quality
How to onboard AI into your organisation, and avoid spending hours setting up new tools
Why mindset is everything – and how early adopters are getting ahead fast.
This workshop is built for:
✔️ Both AI beginners and curious dabblers
✔️ Business owners and operators
✔️ SME teams across any sector: retail, trades, services, health, education, not-for-profit, and more
✔️ Anyone who’s been avoiding AI or feeling overwhelmed by the hype.

You’ll walk away with:
A clear, practical understanding of how AI works and how to use it
Proven tools tailored for small businesses
Plug-and-play workflows to save time and reduce mental load
Confidence to use AI without compromising your brand, your values, or your people.
No tech jargon. No hype. Just real-world tools, clear explanations, and fresh thinking for busy people in any business.
*2024 Work Trend Index Annual Report from Microsoft and LinkedIn
Don’t just take our word for it
People from all over the country have attended our AI workshops. Check out some feedback below.
“Loved it, great balanced presentation, lots covered but the pace was good.  Very different to other tech-based presentations without all the 'show-off jargon'.  Lizi was passionate but realistic and gave the pros and cons.  An intentional and thoughtful presentation, thank you.”
“You made such a daunting topic so easy and clear to understand and navigate.”
“Thank you for a fantastic session this morning. I’ve come away with a whole lot more knowledge and food for thought than I was anticipating and feel empowered to start implementing AI tools from today.”

About Lizi Guest (your workshop facilitator)
I’m the founder of Little & Loud, an award-winning public relations and communications agency that’s worked with more than a hundred organisations; from local councils and government agencies to fast-growing businesses and national brands.

I’ve spent my career helping teams work smarter, minimise risks and leverage opportunities that come from doing business in our fast-changing world. I’ve been working with AI tools in real-world settings, working out what actually works and applying these lessons across our broad client base. My focus is on making AI accessible, ethical, and practical for people who don’t have time to waste. After all, tech should make your job easier, not harder.

id: Annual Women's Debate 2025: Parity in Politics-33 Bunny Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Annual Women's Debate 2025: Parity in Politics
venue: 33 Bunny Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
With local elections fast approaching this October 2025, what is being done to achieve a #GenderEqualNZ within our political systems?
In the 2022 local government elections, only 38% of candidates were women. Despite this being an increase from previous years, significant structural and cultural barriers persist for women seeking to enter and remain in politics.
From issues around childcare to gender-based violence to stereotypes in the media, women experience hostility at all levels of the political sphere. Several women in local government across the country spoke with Breakfast in April, sharing the hateful comments they’ve received online, with abuse and violent threats often spilling into the real world.
So how do we encourage more women into political leadership, and what needs to be done to keep them there?
The Wellington Branch of National Council of Women New Zealand, in collaboration with Graduate Women Wellington and Zonta Club of Wellington, are hosting The Annual Women’s Debate 2025 to discuss this question.
The event will be hosted by award-winning journalist and broadcaster for RNZ, Susie Ferguson. She'll be joined by a stellar line-up of women:
Susan Freeman-Greene, Chief Executive of Local Government New Zealand
Tory Whanau, Mayor of Wellington City
Afnan Al-Rubayee, senior public servant and community leader
Rebecca Matthews, Wellington City Councillor
This year’s Annual Women’s Debate will focus on the experiences of women from across the political spectrum and the gendered obstacles they have faced in politics. Furthermore, the debate will explore what is being done to address barriers to women’s political leadership, and how women representatives can empower a #GenderEqualNZ.
Light refreshments will be available from 5:30pm before the debate starts at 6:00pm.

id: Big Tech Unplug Install Party-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix

id: Introduction to Meshtastic-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Introduction to Meshtastic
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
As the Christchurch Earthquake and Cyclone Gabrielle have shown, in an environmental disaster, Internet infrastructure and mobile communications are unreliable at best.
This 2 hour session will introduce participants to the Meshtastic platform, a post-internet mesh network in broad use in Pōneke/Wellington. Meshtastic allows for sending messages even in a total blackout, right from your phone. The Lower North Island already enjoys a very populous and active Meshtastic mesh, with many members focused on preparedness. Come and learn how you can help strengthen and grow the community! 
A $5 koha will be appreciated.

id: Radio Cartography-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Radio Cartography
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description: This one day event will involve getting out and about around Wellington CBD in an attempt to map it for radio shadows (communication blindspots) within the Lower North Island Meshtastic network. The outcome will be a map which identifies areas where we need to install nodes to give coverage across the CBD. These could become mission-critical to reaching loved ones in the event of an earthquake or blackout event. We will meet at Critical Signals, 115 Taranaki Street, then head out into the city, rain or shine.

id: Social media as infrastructure for democracy-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Social media as infrastructure for democracy
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description: Evan Henshaw-Plath, known as "rabble," is an activist and technologist passionate about building commons-based social media apps that prioritize equity and sustainability.  As the head of the tech team at Odeo when Twitter was created, rabble has unique insights into how social media platforms evolve and the values that shape them.   Rabble will discuss how social media might support democratic processes rather than follow a business model based in surveillance.

id: Server Gardening with Julian Oliver-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Server Gardening with Julian Oliver
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
This lecture, delivered by Julian Oliver, will introduce participants to the potentials and pitfalls of self-hosted server infrastructure, whether that be a PC-turned-server hosted at home, studio or office, or on a server rented at a datacenter. Starting points for self-hosting will be covered, with an introduction to system administration in the context of digital caretaker, guardian and gardener. The lecture will position self-hosting as an act of infrastructural resistance and reclamation in an era of pervasive digital imperialism and extractivism.
  The talk will also assess free and open source platform alternatives to Big Tech, from cloud, to webmail, forum, team chat, and more.

id: Sculpt the City: Explore Risk and Resilience in clay-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Sculpt the City: Explore Risk and Resilience in clay
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Get hands-on with air-dry clay as we reimagine Wellington’s CBD at scale. In this collaborative workshop, we’ll explore how we think about natural hazard risk and resilience—through shape, texture, and place.
By treating the city as a model we can mold, you’ll gain new insights into scale, design, and the ways we interpret our shared environment. No experience is needed—just bring your curiosity, your observational eye, and a willingness to work with others.
The clay city model of the Wellington CBD you help create will be a central reference point throughout the Critical Signals series.
We suggest making a koha of around $5 to cover materials used in this event. 
About the host
Mairéad de Róiste is an Associate Professor at Te Herenga Waka Victoria University of Wellington, specialising in geospatial science. Her work uses maps, spatial data, and hands-on crafting methods to help people understand places, make decisions, and communicate complex ideas clearly. She is passionate about creative, accessible approaches to sharing and understanding geographic information. She also shares her work and that of her collaborators and students in the SpatialThink Lab on Instagram.
SpatialThink Lab: https://www.instagram.com/spatialthinklab/

id: Offline Aotearoa!-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Offline Aotearoa!
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
This fun, one day session builds upon a simple thought experiment: Aotearoa wakes up one day disconnected from the Internet, and the rest of the world. However, local infrastructure, from cell towers, to datacentres and fibre networks, remain unscathed. What could (or couldn't) we do with what we have? What of our current network and communications infrastructure, and all our most used sites and services, would function when we’re ‘cut off’ from the rest of civilisation?
  Join us in a playful lab environment helping build the first ‘map’ of what our digital experience would look like if it was just us - from healthcare, to education, banking and the big socials. In doing so, we’ll get a sense of just how infrastructurally independent – and resilient — we are as a nation.
  Participants will learn how to use simple network probing and website analysis to pull websites and networks apart, looking under the hood at just how much is hosted overseas.
  This is a team effort, with no prior knowledge required. Participants should bring a laptop.

id: Shared Stories: Asset Mapping for Disaster Preparedness-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Shared Stories: Asset Mapping for Disaster Preparedness
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Shared stories: asset mapping for disaster preparedness
 Join us to create and map together our shared knowledge and assets to build collective community resilience. No prior knowledge needed!
 Anna Brown is a research co-lead of the project Ngā Ngaru Wakapuke; a climate and disaster research project. As part of this mapping exercise she will share her work with several communities in Tairāwhiti, Wairarapa and Ōtautahi/Christchurch around mapping, disaster resilience and storytelling. She describes maps as more than locational tools; as a way to build a common understanding of shared assets.
 Anna will lead us through an exercise to record Wellington CBD’s community points of interest, that will be added to over the course of Critical Signals.
 About the host
Anna Brown is a designer, researcher and educator. She is Professor of Design and Public Good at Massey University’s College of Creative Arts. She founded and leads Toi Āria: Design for Public Good. She uses design to create positive change by bringing together organisations, government, and communities — especially making sure the people most affected by decisions have a say in shaping them.

id: Weather Commoning: Chris Berthelsen-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Weather Commoning: Chris Berthelsen
venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Critical Signals from the Japanese Government's Moonshot Goal 8 Project
The Japanese government's Moonshot Goal 8 project aims to create a society safe from extreme winds and rains by controlling the weather by 2050. Led by Kosei Yamaguchi (Kyoto University), a key part of the project is developing devices like turbines, curtains, and cloud seeding to calm (not control) extreme rain. The Weather Commons Research Group, led by Tsuyoshi Hatori (Ehime University), is developing and exploring 'weather commoning’. This involves the exploration of symbiotic relationships with weather patterns and disasters, non-normative ethics based on local community practices, and citizen participation in technological development.
Please join weather commons group leader Tsuyoshi Hatori and member Chris Berthelsen (originally Tāmaki Makaurau) for an introduction to the state of weather control, calming, and commoning research and activity in Japan. This is a space for open discussion, but you are also free to sit back and listen.

id: Electrify Levin: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey-32 Bristol Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Electrify Levin: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey
venue: 32 Bristol Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand
description:
It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Levin will show you how.  
Most Levin homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Levin has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Levin.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Levin is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.

venue: 136 Randwick Road, Moera, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
description:
"Ko te Wairua Tapu te Puna o te Hauora": the Holy Spirit is the wellspring of wellbeing.
All welcome to a day growing our faith-based counselling competence and bicultural relationships.
Learn from the Te Kakano o te Aroah team about their approach to Māori mental health: with Rev. Te Tokaia Nohotima and Molly Raupi Kino.
Reflect on your theology of counselling with Revs Diane Gilliam-Weeks and Reg Weeks
Be part of NZCCA's bicultural journey and learn about our new name: Te Rōpū Tohutohu Karaitiana o Aotearoa
Be refreshed in worship and prayer and friendship.
Cost is $65, including lunch.
1/2 price for students!
This is a training event of the Wellington branch of Te Rōpū Tohutohu Karaitiana o Aotearoa, New Zealand Christian Counsellors Association.
Diane and Reg are both Presbyterian ministers, based in Eastbourne. Between them they bring rich experience in ministry, chaplaincy, Spiritual Direction, supervision and leadership. They will lead an afternoon session with us, reflecting on:
1. What does it mean to be a professional with faith?
2. What tools are in the box of our practice and in our clients’ lives that can contribute to wholeness?
3. What unhelpful beliefs might need to be brought into the light for the benefit of our clients?
Photo is of the Baptism font at Te Kakano o te Aroha Presbyterian Church, Moera, Lower Hutt.

description:
If you know Aotearoa history — and feel the weight of it — but you're unsure how to show up in everyday moments with integrity and impact, this workshop is your next step.
In celebration of Matariki, we’re calling in those who are ready to do more than just know — those who are ready to act.
Join us for an immersive, transformative wānanga series designed to move you from passive awareness to active, accountable allyship.
WORKSHOP ONE - 6 JUNE 9-4
A full-day wānanga to weave relationships, build trust, and grow accountable allyship through values-based connection, storytelling, and Indigenous-led practice.
WORKSHOP TWO - 18 JULY 9-4
A dynamic day of kōrero, games, courageous conversations and collective action to deepen allyship, explore accountability, and grow relational skills grounded in Te Tiriti o Waitangi.
Cost: Free or koha
Who is running it?
The Intersection is a collaboration between Sarah Morris (Pākehā, Ngāpuhi), and Jewelz Petley (Te Rarawa, Ngati Kuri) who will co-facilitate the workshops. Sarah lives in Te Awa Kairangi and is a policy and social change consultant with an interest in accountable allyship. Jewelz Petley (Te Rarawa, Ngati Kuri) based in Tāmaki Makaurau is a social change advocate with a strong focus on equity, allyship, and Te Tiriti-led practice.

id: UpliftED: Empowering Educators | Strengthening the Profession | Shaping the Future-Wallace Street, Mount Cook, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: UpliftED: Empowering Educators | Strengthening the Profession | Shaping the Future
venue: Wallace Street, Mount Cook, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
description:
The UpliftEd Conference is an energising and thought-provoking event designed for educators who are passionate about their profession and the future of education in Aotearoa. Hosted by the Aotearoa Educators' Collective, this conference brings together leading thinkers, researchers, and practitioners to explore what it truly means to uplift and empower teachers.
Expect inspiring keynotes, engaging panel discussions, and opportunities to connect with fellow educators who share your vision for the future of teaching and learning.
Thursday 30 October – Keynote Speakers & Discussions
Opening Keynote: Professor Guy Claxton
Renowned education thinker Guy Claxton will deliver a one-hour keynote, setting the stage for two days of deep thinking and discussion.
Other featured speakers include*:
Professor Peter O’Connor 
Professor Russell Bishop
Dr Simon McCallum 
Dr Hana O'Regan
Dr. Julia Atkin
Janelle Riki-Waaka 
Dr. Michael Johnston
Sitting Members of Parliament Panel
*More speakers to be announced soon. 
Key Themes:
Uplifting the Profession – Trusting teachers and celebrating their expertise
Silver Linings – Finding optimism and opportunity in education
Empowering Educators – Strengthening teacher agency and professionalism
Diversity in Education – Ensuring equity and inclusion
Te Tiriti o Waitangi – Honouring Te Tiriti and its foundational place in education
Future-Focused Learning – Looking ahead to innovative, evidence-informed approaches rather than returning to outdated models
What is the Purpose of School? – A critical exploration of education’s role
Friday 31 October – Unconference & Special Interest Groups
Building on the ideas and challenges presented by speakers, Friday will be a dynamic, participant-driven day where educators engage in deeper discussion and action planning.
Unconference Sessions – Attendees will propose and lead discussions around key themes, sharing insights and strategies in an informal, collaborative environment.
Special Interest Groups – Spaces for educators to connect around shared areas of passion, from Te Tiriti-based education to innovative assessment practices.
Networking Opportunities – Create meaningful connections with educators, researchers, and advocates from across Aotearoa.
Who Should Attend?
Teachers at all levels, from ECE to secondary
School leaders and policymakers
Researchers and academics
Education advocates and community leaders
Early Bird Registration
Take advantage of our early bird discount – register by 28 April 2025 to secure your spot at a reduced rate.  All tickets include access to both days of the conference and catering.

name: BSLA | University of Canterbury, Cohort 5 Wellington workshop: 18th and 19th August 2025
venue: 147 The Terrace, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
This registration is for the two-day in-person workshop on 18th August and 19th August 2025 in Wellington at the James Cook Hotel Grand Chancellor.
The in-person workshop will run from 9.00am - 3.30pm both days. You must also attend a 3rd day online on 4 September OR 5 September (select one date for 3rd day session) as part of this PLD.
Catering for the in-person workshops will be provided, but this PLD does not include transport costs or accommodation.
When registering, you will need to select from one of our tailored learning options, so we can best cater our content to your role. The options are:
Option One: Class Teaching (Years 0-3) in BSLA Structured Literacy Teaching: Most suitable for teachers working with learners in Phase 1 of the ELA curriculum; year 0-3 learners.

Option Two: Class Teaching (Years 4-8) in BSLA Structured Literacy Teaching: Most suitable for teachers working with learners in Phase 2 and 3 of the ELA curriculum; year 4-8 learners.

Option Three: Literacy Leadership (Years 0-8) in BSLA Structured Literacy Teaching: Most suitable for roles with responsibility for literacy leadership and literacy support within or across schools (e.g., RTLits, RTLBs, literacy leads, SENCOs, LSCs, APs, DPs or principals).
You will also need to provide your ARN number (this was sent to your school in an email confirming your funding and looks like SLA_PLD_App-000XXXXX) to complete your workshop registration.
Our amazing team of facilitators are so excited to guide you through this PLD.

If you have any questions, please email Choose BSLA Shared Mailbox
Don't forget to download your ticket to keep all the information handy and confirm your selected tailored learning option.

id: EVolocity Arduino Workshop - Wellington 2025-Trentham, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: EVolocity Arduino Workshop - Wellington 2025
venue: Trentham, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand
description:
This workshop is for EVolocity students or those interested in our program for Years 7 - 13. 
Explore electronics & programming and learn how to build a dashboard for your EV.

Our Arduino programming experts will take you through a step-by-step tutorial on building and programming your Arduino-based system monitor for your own electric vehicle. Our Tech Team have been hard at work developing new Arduino workshop content and hardware, which is intended to be much more concise, and more useful to teams who are wanting to get a foot in the door with programming and data-related electronics. For Open Class teams, you must monitor the temperature of lithium batteries as per the rules, and everyone will leave the Arduino workshop with a working temperature monitoring system. This workshop is essential for those using lithium batteries.
WHAT WE WILL COVER
• Understand what an Arduino is and how it works
• Learn how to use an Arduino safely, and how to program your Arduino using code you've written
• Begin making a dashboard for your electric vehicle to provide performance data
• Along the way, you will learn valuable programming constructs such as variables, conditionals, loops etc
If this is new to you, you won't be alone! No experience is necessary.
ARDUINO KIT
If you are attending the workshop, you will need to purchase a kit. The kits will be provided at the workshop and you'll be sent an invoice following the event. Kits are $45+GST. If you aren’t intending on coming along to the workshop but would like to purchase a kit, please let us know.
WHAT TO BRING
There is a chance that the University computers may have driver issues, so as a back up, students are to bring their own computers. The programming software is free, and please ensure this is installed and tested in advance. THE REQUIRED SOFTWARE DOES NOT RUN ON CHROMEBOOKS. Please download Arduino IDE 2 (the one at the top of the page), and ensure you are using a Windows, Mac, or Linux computer. There may be some devices available on the day for those who do not have a device. You can download the Arduino Guidebook and Example Sketches here. The booklet steps you through the connections and programming, and the example sketches are what you will work from during the workshop.
Please bring a snack and a drink bottle.
Location
Upper Hutt College, Engineering Workshop Room T2, Theory Room T6.
Parking
Free parking available on site.
Contact
School Co-Ordinator / Annabelle Batchelor / 027 4100 633 / annabelle@evolocity.co.nz

Students bring their vehicles and scrutineers assess them as fit-for-purpose for race day. It's important that all teams participate in pre-scrutineering to ensure you are on track for your vehicle to meet the technical specifications and safety requirements necessary for race day.

id: STEAMS School BLENHEIM Term 3 2025-Mayfield, Blenheim 7201, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: STEAMS School BLENHEIM Term 3 2025
venue: Mayfield, Blenheim 7201, New Zealand
description:
STEAMS is an integrated approach to learning topics of Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Maths, and Society that fosters critical thinking, problem solving, communication and collaboration. Its aim is to teach real world skills through engaging methods whilst allowing individuals to be creative. This involves immersing tamariki into projects and activities that develop innovation and champion curiosity. STEAMS is not ‘play based learning’ but focused learning through an integrated hands-on approach allowing children to take risks and explore their own curiosity in a subject without time barriers.
At the Ministry of Inspiration we offer STEAMS learning each term for Year 1-8 students. Once a week students will attend a class at Waterlea Racecourse, Blenheim on TUESDAY or THURSDAY. STEAMS Jr (ages 7-9) start at 9am and finish at 2:45pm on TUESDAY. Little STEAMerS operates from 12-3 on TUESDAY. STEAMS Sr (ages 10-13) operates on THURSDAY from 9am to 245 pm. We qualify as an off-site learning programme which enables schools to record the students as “learning offsite” rather than absent for that day.
Inquiry, collaboration, and an emphasis on process-based learning are at the heart of the STEAM approach. Each term the classes will have a focus which drives the learning and our amazing teachers create opportunities to help each student develop their understanding, improve their skills and gain knowledge in a range of topics.
Students who participate in STEAM learning:
· think outside the box
· feel safe to express innovative and creative ideas
· feel comfortable doing hands-on learning
· take ownership over their learning
· work collaboratively with others
· understand the ways that science, maths, the arts, and technology work together
· become increasingly curious about the world around them and feel empowered to change it for the better.
When does it meet, and where?
The school is held during school terms.
STEAMS Jr (ages 7-9) TUESDAY, 9-245.
STEAMS Sr (ages 10-13) THURSDAY, 9-245
Little STEAMerS (ages 5-6) TUESDAY 12-3.
Location:  Waterlea Racecourse, enter off of Linton St.
How much does it cost?
The students come for a paid three-week trial-as a new student you pay for that through Humanitix.
If both family and teacher feel there is a good fit for the child in the class, they continue for the rest of the term. You are then invoiced for the full term less the amount paid for the Trial.
Payment is by term, with a cost of $63 per day plus GST. We have a limited number of scholarships available that are awarded on a term by term basis for those with financial need for 25% off. 
Little STEAMerS is $25 per day plus GST.
Will my child’s school mind that they miss a day per week?
You will need to inform the child’s school that he or she will be at STEAMS School one day per week. To date we have not encountered any issues around accommodating a child’s participation in STEAMS School, and many of the region’s schools are very supportive of the programme. Once enrolled, you are encouraged to inform the teacher and office staff that your child should be marked present for the day they attend STEAMS School, as they will be attending an academic school as opposed to being absent due to illness or other reasons.

Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.

“Jane Austen Wrecked My Life is a romantic comedy for the quiet, thoughtful lovers who yearn for the sincerity of the past."- Jourdain Searles, Roger Ebert
"Jane Austen Wrecked My Life, an amiable new romance written and directed by Laura Piani. Steeped in the filmmaker's love of the writer" - John Powers, NPR
"It is a truth universally acknowledged that Jane Austen has inspired more romcoms than any other author – and nearly all of them feature a modern take on an Austen protagonist, a new Lizzie Bennet or Emma Woodhouse. A 2023 British musical romance film, written and directed by Janis Pugh, winning two BAFTA Cymru awards in 2024 for Best feature and Breakthrough, and Official Selection at Toronto International Film Festival.
Chuck Chuck Baby is a film of love, loss and music set amongst the falling feathers of a chicken factory.

About the film:
Under the celestial guidance of Matariki, kuia Hamo (Hinetu Dell) and the troubled Jo (Darneen Christian) form an unlikely bond on a road trip. As they confront painful histories and navigate the weight of their pasts, their shared journey becomes one of healing, community, and reconciliation.
Set against the breathtaking landscapes of Aotearoa, Kōkā marks the debut feature from director Kath Akuhata-Brown (Ngāti Porou) and is the first film told entirely in the original Ngāti Porou dialect - brought to life through the guidance of language and tikanga experts Erana Reedy and Karepe McDonald.
Produced by Verity Mackintosh and Libby Hakaraia, Kōkā was made with a predominantly Māori cast and crew, and nurtured emerging talent through the Māoriland Film Festival’s rangatahi programme
At its heart, this is a story of reconnection — with whenua, with whakapapa, and with each other.

New Zealand's most talented baristas will be brewing to win the national title in Upper Hutt on Saturday 23 and Sunday 24 August. They are also in the running to win “The People’s Champion” where you can be the judge.

The Road to the Aotearoa Barista Champs 2025
The main event — the Aotearoa Barista Champs 2025 — will take place this October, four months after the regional competitions.
You do not need to compete at regionals to enter Nationals; however, spots to compete are limited. Priority will be given to the top four competitors from each regional event, who will have first access to entry.
🏅 Regional Champions automatically secure a place at Nationals as part of their prize package.
🥈 2nd to 4th place finishers will also have spots reserved for them and receive 50% off their entry fee.
These reserved spots must be claimed via a special entry channel before general entries open on the 28 April. Details on how to register will be shared directly with place-getters after each regional event.
Who Will Be Crowned the Aotearoa Barista Champion 2025?
This is New Zealand’s most prestigious coffee competition — the pinnacle of barista craft, skill, and passion.
The winner will go on to represent Aotearoa at the World Barista Championship 2026, with flights and accommodation included as part of the prize.

id: Huntress x A Lady Butcher : Whole Hog Workshop + Wine-Martinborough 5711, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Huntress x A Lady Butcher : Whole Hog Workshop + Wine
venue: Martinborough 5711, New Zealand
description:
Step into a unique fusion of skills, storytelling, and indulgence with Huntress and A Lady Butcher. This immersive event combines a hands-on butchery workshop with the luxury of wine pairing & artisan charcuterie to match. You’ll learn how these two worlds—vinification & butchery—intersect, while enjoying a curated selection of wines & charcuterie that embody the spirit of the land.
What to Expect:
Huntress Experience:
Guided by "The Huntress", Jannine Rickards, a passionate advocate for sustainable living and wild wine, you’ll be introduced to a deep, meaningful connection between the land, the food we consume, and the wines we enjoy. Shaped by a childhood spent in the hills of the Coromandel Peninsula and years of honing her skills in the Wairarapa, Jannine brings a lifetime of knowledge to the table.
This workshop is about honoring the land’s intricate balance and how that is showcased in wine. Alongside her teachings, you’ll discover how Huntress Wines reflect indigenous food-growing practices and how each bottle celebrates the connection between the land’s cycles and the wines that grow from them.
A Lady Butcher Experience:
While immersing yourself in the art of wine making, Hannah Miller Childs, aka. A Lady Butcher will guide you through the ancient craft of butchery and curing meat. She’ll show you how to break down a whole poaka before methodically curing it into what will become coppa, all the while offering valuable tips on everything from ethical sourcing to the most efficient techniques. Whether you’re a seasoned chef or a complete novice, this session will leave you with practical skills to take home—plus a deeper understanding of the land-to-table journey.
Wine Pairing:
As you absorb all the knowledge from the Huntress and Butcher, you’ll enjoy expertly paired wines throughout the experience. Huntress Wines have been carefully chosen to complement each stage of the workshop, with a focus on organic, terroir-driven bottles that reflect the spirit of the land and match exquisitely with the charcuterie selection prepared. Sip on hand-picked reds, whites, and rosés while snacking on a selection of cured meats and engaging with the instructors and fellow participants.
What to Bring:
Comfortable attire (workshop may involve handling tools and light physical activity)
An open mind and a love of new experiences
Limited Spots Available!
Join us for a memorable Sunday afternoon of skill-building, wine tasting, and a deeper connection to the land. This is a one-of-a-kind workshop that celebrates sustainable practices, the art of butchery, and the symbiotic relationship between the food we eat and the wine we drink.
Reserve Your Spot Now!

The conversations that will shape the future of vocational education are happening here. Will you be in the room?
This is not just another industry event—it’s where findings become action. Tūhura: Te Māramatanga ki ngā Tukanga – Insights to Actions is your chance to be part of a gathering that will define the future of vocational education in Aotearoa’s construction and infrastructure sectors.
ConCOVE has been at the forefront of research and innovation in vocational education, and this flagship event is our opportunity to share the latest research and the steps you can take to create change where it matters the most: in workplaces, training providers, and policy development.

· Real-world impact. Learn how our research is already driving change—inside organisations, across policy, and in training programmes.

name: Gong Bath at Newtown Community Centre
venue: Colombo Street &, Rintoul Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
description:
***$20***
Limited door sales for $25
*Please bring a yoga mat, pillow, eye mask and blanket for maximum comfort and warmth*
Discover the transformative effects of sound therapy with this 1-hour gong bath experience.
During this session, participants will be surrounded by the resonant vibrations of gongs, carefully designed to induce deep states of relaxation and calm. As you settle into the experience, allow the soothing tones to wash over you, releasing tension and promoting a sense of inner peace.
Scientific studies have highlighted the benefits of sound therapy, particularly gong baths, in reducing stress and promoting overall well-being. The rhythmic patterns and frequencies of the gongs can help entrain brainwaves, leading to a meditative state and improved mental clarity.
Beyond the immediate effects, many participants report experiencing lasting benefits such as improved sleep, reduced anxiety, and enhanced mood following a gong bath session. By immersing yourself in the healing vibrations of the gongs, you can tap into a deeper sense of relaxation and rejuvenation.
Whether you're looking to unwind after a long day or explore new avenues of self-care, this 1-hour gong bath offers a unique opportunity to reconnect with yourself and find balance amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life. There will be cups of tea available afterwards to help us integrate and ground
**THIS EVENT IS RESTRICTED TO 20 PEOPLE ONLY**
About Me
Erika is a musician and astrologer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She has 30+ years musical experience. Erika has an interest in the healing properties of sound for mental and physical wellbeing, which she currently explores through her gong bathing practice

id: Wellington - Information Lecture: A Path to a Healthy Body & Soul-7 Moncrieff Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BvGE7HCJEtw&t=4s
Help and Healing on the Spiritual Path through the teaching of Bruno Groening - Medically Verifiable.
With the growing awareness of holistic medicine, the possibility for healing on the spiritual path is finding increasing attention, even in professional circles.
Bruno Groening (1906-1959) brought a simple message: there is a higher power that is the basis of all living things and it can heal. He showed how this energy can be absorbed freely into the body, and through his teaching many people were cured back then as today, even from diseases that are considered incurable.
Numerous medically documented success reports demonstrate the current effects of his teaching. These success reports have been proven and documented within the Medical Scientific Group – a world-wide forum of independent medical doctors, psychologists and health care professionals within the Bruno Groening Circle of Friends.
Our Information Lecture is open to all interested people. Feel free to invite friends or family who you think may benefit.

id: Ceremonial Cacao, psychedelics, and neuroplasticity - exploring shamanic practices of Peru-147 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Ceremonial Cacao, psychedelics, and neuroplasticity - exploring shamanic practices of Peru
venue: 147 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Join us for an immersive workshop  that bridges ancient indigenous traditions with cutting-edge neuroscience to explore the powerful intersection of cacao, psychedelics, and spiritual transformation.
In this workshop, you will discover the rich history and sacred significance of cacao in indigenous cultures, focusing on its use in ancient Peru. Learn about the temples, tribes, tools, and symbols associated with cacao, as well as its role in shamanic rituals. We will delve into the cosmovision that links cacao with psychedelic plant medicines and how these ancient practices are integrated with modern scientific understanding.
Key Highlights:
-The Sacred Role of Cacao: Explore the origins of cacao in the ancient temple of Montegrande and Chavín de Huántar, Peru, key sites of shamanic initiation dating back over 7000 years. Shamans used ceremonial cacao to connect with the divine and combined it with San Pedro cactus to induce visionary experiences.
-Cacao & Neuroscience: Understand how ceremonial cacao influences brain chemistry and supports spiritual awakening and neuroplasticity. We'll discuss the latest neuroscience research on cacao’s ability to facilitate transformational change and rewiring of the brain.
-Cacao Personality Mapping: Through biochemical mapping, we have developed a "Cacao Personality Map" to help you tailor your cacao experience to your personal needs, whether for healing, insight, or emotional clarity.
-Integrating Tradition & Modern Science: Learn how ancient practices are validated and enhanced through contemporary neuroscience, and discover how cacao can be a tool for deep inner work and to enhance both mental and physical health.

If you’re passionate about cacao and curious about its transformative potential, this workshop  will expand your understanding and deepen your connection with this sacred plant. Whether you’re a cacao lover or a seeker on a spiritual path, this experience will open your mind to the possibilities cacao holds for healing, awakening, and change.
Date: Wed 30th Jul 2025, 7:00 - 9.00 pm NZST
Location: Commonsense Wellington, 147 Tory Street
Tickets: Book online from $5-15 (ultra early bird - late pre-sales)
Extras: Get 10% off all Seleno Health products after the event and a free sample cup of a creamy ceremonial cacao elixir during the workshop.
Presenter:
Dr Corin Storkey (PhD – Med Chem) has over 20 years of academic and research experience, specialising in understanding how plant medicines interact with the brain and body. He holds a PhD in medicinal chemistry from the University of Melbourne. He has previously overcome chronic fatigue syndrome and promotes an integrative and holistic approach to managing chronic health conditions. He currently leads the New Zealand based Andean/Amazonian plant medicine research program that studies ancestral plants and substantiates their traditions through biochemical analysis.

id: Beneath the Surface - Somatic Dance-293 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Beneath the Surface - Somatic Dance
venue: 293 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
BENEATH THE SURFACE
A somatic dance journey
Join embodiment facilitators Jenna Joan & Sonic Sutra for a cosy, new moon gathering of ceremonial cacao, freeform movement, and live soundscape.
🌑 Friday 25 July
🕕 6–8pm
📍 Thistle Hall Community Venue
🎟️ $35–$45
✨ Sober · Non-judgemental · All welcome · No experience needed
Take a quiet winter evening to slow down, soften your body, and reconnect to your inner world...

Beneath the Surface is a warm, intimate space to move, breathe, and listen deeply to your body—just as it is.
We’ll begin with ceremonial cacao, then drop into a guided movement journey with a live soundscape. There are no steps to learn, no performance—just presence, curiosity, and letting your body do the talking. Barefoot and phone-free, you’re invited to move as you feel—awakening warmth, inner truth, and expression.
Come as you are.
Move as you feel.
Leave feeling more connected, warm, and alive.
Somatic dance is a guided movement practice that helps you tune into your body’s wisdom and move from the inside out. Unlike ecstatic dance, which is typically an open, DJ-led space with no facilitation, somatic dance offers gentle guidance to support you in exploring sensation, emotion, and embodiment in a safe, intentional way. You’re not learning steps or performing—you're being invited into presence, curiosity, and feeling. With a focus on nervous system regulation, personal expression, and inner listening, somatic dance creates a nurturing space to come home to yourself.
Your Hosts...
Jenna Joan | Embodiment Facilitator
Jenna Joan is a somatic therapist, yoga teacher, and group facilitator who has been leading movement spaces for over 15 years. With a background in yoga, somatic dance, and therapeutic embodiment, her work blends play, authenticity, and deep nervous system awareness. Jenna is also a cacao alchemist and ceremonial facilitator, known for creating safe, soulful spaces that invite freedom, connection, and inner exploration. She has been hosting workshops, retreats, and community events for nearly a decade, and also works 1:1 in more therapeutic settings.
Sonic Sutra | Somatic Dance DJ
Sonic Sutra is a sound artist and somatic dance DJ who creates immersive musical journeys designed to support authentic movement, emotional release, and deep embodiment. With a focus on somatic dance and therapeutic soundscapes, their sets are intentionally curated to guide dancers through an inner experience—honouring the body’s natural rhythms and the intelligence within. Their offerings create safe, accessible spaces for people of all bodies, backgrounds, and experience levels to explore movement, presence, and connection. Rooted in play, precision, and deep listening, Sonic Sutra brings music that moves beyond entertainment—into healing and transformation.

id: Co:Lab 2025 - New Zealand's Lab Sector Forum-4 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Co:Lab 2025 - New Zealand's Lab Sector Forum
venue: 4 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
You're invited to New Zealand's Lab Sector Forum - Co:Lab 2025
Brought to you by the Awanui Group 

CoLab 2025 will bring together industry leaders, healthcare professionals, and experts to share strategies, case studies, and present interesting perspectives on the future of the roll of pathology laboratories in healthcare.

Co:Lab 2025 is delivered across two thought-provoking days with presentations from thought-leaders from both within and outside the sector. This event is designed to get the lab network together, face-to-face, so all our speakers are delivering presentations in-person.
This year's theme is Pathology in Partnership: Strengthening Collaboration Across Healthcare. With an increasing need for an interconnected health sector, the role of pathology laboratories extends beyond diagnostics - acting as a vital link between various healthcare disciplines.
This year, we will explore how enhanced partnerships and new and interesting collaborations can drive improved patient outcomes, from primary care to cutting-edge specialties. We’ll explore how laboratories could evolve to support integrated care models, leverage emerging technologies, and foster data-driven insights that empower clinicians and patients alike.
As usual, this forum offers plenty of opportunities for networking and discussion with the sector.
TICKETS

- Early Bird: $479 + GST get in early before the programme is announced to secure $90 off your ticket. Admission to all sessions, catering and the evening networking and dinner function.
- General: $569 + GST admission to all sessions, catering and the evening networking and dinner function.

id: Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions-1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Porirua 5024, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions
venue: 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Porirua 5024, New Zealand
description:
Doctors For Nutrition and MTM Charity invite you to an evening of inspiration, education, and connection at our next ‘Dine with a Doc’ dinner.
Join us for a presentation on ‘The Power of Plant-Based Nutrition and Lifestyle Interventions for Preventing Chronic Disease’—an event designed to empower everyone from healthcare professionals to health-conscious community members. You will also be the first to hear about the new MTM charity, and about their mission. 
When: 6:30pm – 9:30pm, Tuesday, 19th August 2025
Where: Location: Gear Homestead, 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Wellington
Price: $50 (includes dinner)
At this event, Dr Heleen Haitjema will take you on a journey through the clinical benefits of whole food, plant-based (WFPB) nutrition. Through easy-to-understand explanations of key concepts - such as endothelial dysfunction, intramyocellular lipid accumulation, and calorie density - you’ll discover how WFPB eating can dramatically improve health outcomes and transform lives. 
After the presentation, join us for a panel discussion and a Q&A session with Dr Haitjema and Dr Luke Wilson. 
The evening continues with a plant-based dinner curated by the chefs from MTM charity, served in the elegant setting of Gear Homestead. Enjoy the opportunity to connect and network with leading dietitians, specialists, GPs, and passionate members of New Zealand’s plant-based community.
Buy your tickets now; spaces are strictly limited!

id: Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins and Wade Reeve Live-13 Pirie Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins and Wade Reeve Live
venue: 13 Pirie Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins & Wade Reeve Live
A Tribute to the Queen of the Blues
Dinah Washington, the self-proclaimed “Queen of the Blues,” was a powerhouse of jazz, blues, and soul whose voice defined an era. Now, her timeless repertoire is being reimagined by Aotearoa’s own queen of soulful expression—the incomparable Lisa Tomlins.
Lisa’s vocal versatility is legendary. Whether interpreting Tower of Power, jazz standards, or contemporary pop, she brings depth, warmth, and unmistakable style. She’s graced stages with L.A.B., Fly My Pretties, Neil Finn, and countless others—earning her place as one of New Zealand’s most beloved vocalists.
Joining her is the ever-tasteful guitarist Wade Reeve, whose intuitive playing complements Lisa’s voice with elegance and restraint. If you caught their stunning set at CubaDupa, you already know the magic this duo creates.
Maybe you'll hear Dinah’s most iconic songs—What a Diff’rence a Day Made, Cold, Cold Heart, September in the Rain, and of course, Unforgettable. This afternoon promises to be just that.
🎟️ Capital Blues Members: $10
🎟️ General Admission: $20
🍷 Members also enjoy 10% off at the bar
