id: The Warratahs-11 Logan Street, Ebdentown, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: The Warratahs
venue: 11 Logan Street, Ebdentown, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand
description:
The Warratahs Live at the Upper Hutt Cossie Club – Saturday 2nd August
After nearly four decades on the road, The Warratahs remain one of New Zealand’s most beloved bands — and now they’re returning to the Upper Hutt Cossie Club for a very special show.
With 37 years of touring behind them, The Warratahs have left a deep mark on Kiwi music. Their legacy includes seven studio albums that made the charts, a Tui Music Award for Country Album of the Year in 2017, and performances alongside legends like Johnny Cash & The Highwaymen, Lucinda Williams, and Jackson Browne.
Barry Saunders’ iconic songwriting is woven into the fabric of the New Zealand songbook, and this is your chance to witness the band at their best.
Born out of a simple love for playing music with mates down at the pub, The Warratahs first hit the stage at The Cricketers’ Arms in Wellington in 1986 — never imagining they’d become a national treasure.
Led by the distinctive voice of Barry Saunders and the unmistakable violin of Nik Brown, their sound — forged in 1985 — continues to captivate audiences.
Don’t miss this legendary band live in Upper Hutt!

id: The English Locust & Antü Mãrama Play The Shed-46a Victoria Street, Alicetown, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: The English Locust & Antü Mãrama Play The Shed
venue: 46a Victoria Street, Alicetown, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
description:
The English Locust is the folk/blues solo project of Wellington musician Jim Bailey. The English Locust describes his sound as " Bob Dylan if he was goth", fusing the melancholy poeticism of groups like the Smiths and Joy Division with the musical stylings of folk and Delta Blues.
 Jim is a veteran of the Wellington Music scene, holding a bachelor's degree in commercial music. His previous band The Vermillion Poets, placed second in the national New Zealand battle of the bands in 2019 where he also won an award for best vocalist. With his current group SHE, he has released three singles to critical acclaim from NZ Music.net and was the organiser for their festival SPECTRE FEST for two years. With his solo project The English Locust, he was a regional finalist in this years Battle of the bands, being the only soloist to make it that far in this years competition. He plans to release his debut single late 2025 or early 2026. 
Antü Mārama is a musical collaboration between Paulette Mankoch Soriano (Chile), Jim Bailey (UK) Claudio (Chile), Andres del Vilar (Chile), David (Canary islands) and Catherine Ireland (NZ). The band evolved from a previous incarnation, The flying jaranas, who played primarily Son Jarocho, a traditional music from Veracruz on the East Coast of Mexico. Since then, members have come and gone, and Antü Mārama has broadened its horizons to play folk music from all around Latin America, as well as original compositions written by lead singer Paulette. The group's ethos is represented by the name - Antü is the Mabudungun word for sun, while Mārama is the Te reo Māori word for Moon. The group combines both the life-giving energy and vitality of the sun with the deeper emotions and more reflective energy of the Moon. Antü Mārama is a synthesis of the group's diverse backgrounds and musical experiences, united by a love of playing music, and a desire to share the rich folk tradition of Latin America with a local audience.

id: Candlelit Concerts - it's a night out that feels good and does good!-87 Oxford Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Candlelit Concerts - it's a night out that feels good and does good!
venue: 87 Oxford Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand
description:
Step into an evening of warmth, wonder, and world-class music at our exclusive Candlelit Concert Series — a magical event that happens only four times a year.
Once each season, our beautifully historic local church is transformed into an intimate haven, softly illuminated by the glow of 200 flickering candles and a gentle wash of laser light. The result? A truly enchanting atmosphere that invites you to pause, breathe, and connect.
Before the music begins, you’ll be welcomed with light refreshments and dessert nibbles, setting the tone for a relaxing, uplifting night. Then settle in for 75 minutes of exquisite acoustic music, carefully curated to soothe the soul and spark joy.
🎟️ Limited to just 100 guests, this is a rare opportunity to enjoy extraordinary live music in a cozy, welcoming setting.
💰 Tickets: $35 each
🕰️ Doors open at 7:00pm, with music starting shortly after 7:30pm — the perfect way to unwind after dinner.
📍 Venue: Our beautifully historic local church, lovingly transformed for the night.
Guest Artists: The Kugels
Take two former New Zealand Symphony Orchestra players, a virtuoso accordionist, and a renowned bass player — and you have The Kugels!
Featuring national champion accordionist Rebekah Greig, former NZSO members Robin Perks (violin) and Debbie Rawson (clarinet), and RNZ classical and jazz expert Nick Tipping (double bass), The Kugels have been captivating audiences across Aotearoa for over 15 years.
Their music draws deeply from Eastern European traditions and beyond, with a special focus on klezmer — a genre that swings between soul-stirring melancholy and infectious joy, moving audiences to laugh, cry, and even dance in the aisles. After nationwide tours with Arts on Tour NZ and Chamber Music New Zealand, and performances at major festivals, The Kugels continue to enchant and inspire wherever they play.
Even more special, each concert helps support valuable community programmes and initiatives — making your night out one that feels good and does good.
Whether you come for the spellbinding music, the magical candlelit setting, or the sense of connection and community, we promise an evening you’ll never forget — and one you’ll want to return to, season after season.
✨ Book your tickets now and be part of this unforgettable experience. ✨
Please note: These concerts are designed for adult audiences; we kindly ask that no children under 10 attend so everyone can fully enjoy the atmosphere.

id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Dave Wilson-1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Dave Wilson
venue: 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
The next concert in our series presents a new project by Dave Wilson titled Free, Free: Meditations on Liberation. This project brings together a collective of musicians from across the music communities of Pōneke in an invitation to explore the expansive possibilities for what liberation might sound like.

Free, Free draws from legacies of musical collectivity, and celebrates a commitment to both collaboration and the distinct expression of each individual.
Ranging from contemplative minimalism to ecstatic ensemble energy and body-moving grooves, the music of Free, Free invites musicians and other listeners to tend to each moment, making their own offerings to shape the collective sound.

Dave Wilson is a saxophonist, clarinettist, composer, producer, and interdisciplinary scholar. His music bridges avant-garde and experimental music with various groove-oriented styles from the worlds of jazz, R&B, electronic music, and more.
 
With his 2023 album Ephemeral, described as “quite spiritually intense music” by The Guardian, he was a finalist for Te Manu Taki Tautito o te Tau | Best Jazz Artist at the Aotearoa Music Awards, and for the APRA Best Jazz Composition Award. Before relocating to Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington in 2016, Dave grew up in the Chicago area, lived for a decade in Los Angeles, and spent several stints living in Skopje, North Macedonia.
 
Free, Free: Meditations on Liberation
Dave Wilson, Tyaan Singh – alto saxophone
Louisa Williamson – tenor saxophone
Monique Lapins, Mana Waiariki – violin
Ken Ichinose – cello
Kaito Walley, Natania Ngawhau – trombone
Ben Hunt – trumpet
Daniel Hayles, Andrew Faleatua – piano and keyboard
Phoebe Johnson – bass
Callum Allardice – guitar
Hikurangi Schaverien-Kaa – drums

The performance will begin with an opening set by Flute Journeys, an offbeat mass flute ensemble with the self-described playing abilities of 5–12-year-olds, embodying a form of liberation in music.

The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.
Thanks to CNZ for their generous support.

id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Callum Passells-Level 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: Callum Passells
venue: Level 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
The seventh concert in our series is a new suite of music by Tāmaki Makaurau composer, performer, and educator; Callum Passells.
For the Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Callum brings new music for his ensemble LCR, an ensemble which features three identical saxophone trios (sax, bass, and drums) that play with and against each other in a kaleidoscopic and often explosive fashion. The new pieces commissioned for this series continue to stretch at the fabric of jazz and improvised forms, and are inspired by Morton Feldman, Lennie Tristano, Henry Threadgill and Sly Stone.
Callum has been deeply involved in the New Zealand jazz and improvised music scene for over a decade, and is a busy freelancer in the wider music community in Auckland. He has performed with Aldous Harding, Hans Pucket, the Exploding Rainbow Orchestra, the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra, among many others. In 2021, Callum was commissioned to compose a large-scale work 'Solid Spirit, Liquid Body' for the Wellington Jazz Festival. He is currently completing a Master of Music degree at the University of Auckland, where he also teaches saxophone.
The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.

id: Niko Ne Zna Live at Vogelmorn Hall (Wellington)-13 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Niko Ne Zna Live at Vogelmorn Hall (Wellington)
venue: 13 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
description:
Wellington, get ready! It’s been a minute!
Fresh off a sold-out show in Auckland, Niko Ne Zna returns to the capital for a night of explosive Balkan brass at Vogelmorn Hall.
Expect bold brass, infectious rhythms, soaring vocals, and a dancefloor that won’t quit. This nine-piece powerhouse delivers their signature high-energy performance — featuring brand new songs in preparation for their upcoming third studio album, as well as all the hits you know and love.
Live Balkan brass music
Delicious food available
Cash bar featuring local beers from Kererū Brewing, as well as wine and spirits from the Balkans
A party like no other
With trumpets, saxophone, trombones, sousaphone, tapan (bass drum), snare drum, percussion, and vocals in multiple languages, Niko Ne Zna blends hypnotic melodies, driving rhythms, and theatrical flair into an unforgettable live experience. Whether on the street, in a club, or on a festival stage, their shows are part gig, part spectacle — all heart.
They’ve wowed crowds at WOMAD, featured in What We Do In The Shadows, and played to packed houses across New Zealand and Australia.
Come early, grab a bite, enjoy a Kererū brew, and be part of something special.
Doors at 6pm.
“It’s like being dropped into the hot and spicy lands of a faraway country.” — wellingtonlivemusic.com
“Straight to the dancefloor.” — Elsewhere
“Driving rhythms, an intoxicating effect.” — Taranaki Daily News
www.nikonezna.com

id: Comfy Concert 5 at The Long Hall - The Chamber Pot Pourri Ensemble performance for Arohanui Strings+-13 Maida Vale Road, Roseneath, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Comfy Concert 5 at The Long Hall - The Chamber Pot Pourri Ensemble performance for Arohanui Strings+
venue: 13 Maida Vale Road, Roseneath, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
🎵 Join us for an afternoon of beautiful music and community spirit! 🎵
Enjoy Beautiful Chamber Music with a View! Relax with a cuppa and a biscuit (koha appreciated!) while listening to expertly curated chamber music featuring Helene, Rolf, and top musicians at an intimate venue in one of Wellington’s most stunning locations.
Helene Pohl (violin) and Rolf Gjelsten (cello), as the Chamber Pot Pourri Ensemble, are getting together with friends to play a series of intimate concerts that support some of their favourite causes – Arohanui Strings+ included (www.arohanuistrings.org).
Comfy Concert No.5 with Bridget Douglas (flute) and Victoria Jaenecke (viola) on August 30, 2025, playing:
Tabea Squire - Daydream and Dance for violin and cello
JS Bach – Sonata No. 1 in G minor for violin solo
Heitor Villa-Lobos – The Jet Whistle for flute and cello
WA Mozart – Flute Quartet in D Major
(programmes and artists may change - but hopefully not!)
The Comfy Concert series 2
Building on the success of the first series of Comfy Concerts from April to June, Helen and Rolf have announced another four concerts to benefit Kaibosh (Saturday 20 September & Saturday 15 November) and Arohanui Strings+ (Saturday 20 August & Saturday 18 November). 
Thank you to Helene, Rolf and musicians of The Chamber Pot Pourri Ensemble, for generously donating time and talent in support Arohanui Strings+ and Kaibosh!
Learn more about these charities: arohanuistrings.org and kaibosh.org.nz
Location
The Long Hall overlooks Point Jerningham with views of Te Whanganui-a-Tara/Wellington Harbour. See the Google map location. You can park on Maida Vale Rd or on Roseneath School tennis court and follow the signs. Or on foot or bike, use the footpath up from Carlton Gore Road or from Maida Vale Road near Roseneath School.
BYO cushion is advised.
It's going to be a wonderful afternoon of fabulous music, while raising funds for two fabulous charities.
Rolf Gjelsten (cello), Helene Pohl (violin)

id: Homegrown Road Trip Tour 2025 | Wellington-69 Courtenay Place, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Homegrown Road Trip Tour 2025 | Wellington
venue: 69 Courtenay Place, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Some of today’s most exciting homegrown talents are heading on tour – Hori Shaw and Shane Walker, with support from Te Wehi, are heading to 10 Kiwi towns and cities this winter. 
The tour, the Homegrown Road Trip, will head to Gisborne, Whakatane, Tauranga, Kaitaia, Hamilton, Rotorua, Napier, Palmerston, New Plymouth and Wellington over four weekends in June, July and August. 
Hori Shaw, Shane Walker and Te Wehi are arguably three of the most popular Kiwi artists in music right now, with all three taking the top three spots on the Official Top 20 Aotearoa Singles Chart. Te Wehi’s cover of Allen Stone’s Unaware; Hori Shaw’s Back in My Arms; and Shane Walker’s Coasty Girl has charted at 1, 2 and 3.
Now, all three are joining forces for the Homegrown Road Trip. Tickets go on sale at 6pm on Thursday, May 8 and are expected to sell out. AfterPay and Zip Pay are both available!
Homegrown Road Trip is Hori Shaw’s first headline tour in NZ, and with hearty supporters all around Aotearoa, these shows are all highly anticipated. 
Hori Shaw has been a major part of New Zealand’s music scene since he released Country Roads in 2023 and his success has continued with further hits Back in My Arms; Shawfyah; and One Day, all released last year. Back in My Arms is arguably his biggest release so far, securing a spot on NZ’s Official Top 40 Singles chart, and a number one spot on the Official Top 20 Aotearoa Singles chart.  
Shane Walker and Te Wehi are also making their mark, also securing spots on NZ’s Official Top 40 Singles chart – Shane Walker with Coasty Girl and Te Wehi with Unaware. These releases have also reached the number one spot on the Official Top 20 Aotearoa Singles chart.  
Since releasing FX*K You Too, Shane Walker has been cementing his place as a powerhouse in today’s music. Coasty Girl has dominated airwaves and his subsequent single Waimā Girl is also making its way up the charts right now.
Te Wehi’s cover of Unaware has been hugely popular and on April 4 it reached number one on the Official Top 20 Aotearoa Singles chart, where it remained for the rest of the month.  
Homegrown Road Trip is a highly anticipated tour – so get in quick to secure tickets. Tickets won’t last long.

id: On a Good Day - EP launch - Hihi & The Stitchbirds-167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: On a Good Day - EP launch - Hihi & The Stitchbirds
venue: 167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
description:
Come celebrate Hihi & The Stitchbirds' first EP - On a Good Day - an exploration of love, and loss, and the pieces in between.
7:00pm - Doors
7:30pm - The Bidibids
8:30pm - Hihi & The Stitchbirds
After a whirlwind 18 months as a five-piece folk band, Hihi & The Stitchbirds are delighted to release their debut EP with five original songs that will make you feel soothed and seen. Written by band members Tess Luff, Elena Saunders and Ellie Stewart, this group of talented musicians invite you into contemplative corners of their brains with a set of gentle and jovial numbers that will entertain and delight.
They will be joined on stage by their friends the Bidibids.
About Hihi & The Stitchbirds:
Hihi & The Stitchbirds are an exciting five-piece musical experiment, based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Pairing rich vocal harmonies with vibrant original music inspired by the folk and Americana playbooks, this band brings something for everyone.
Hihi & The Stitchbirds are:
Elena Saunders - vocals and vibes
Chris Goldsbury - guitar, clarinet and vocals
Tess Luff - guitar, banjo uke and vocals
Matt Hutton - bass uke and vocals
Ellie Stewart - fiddle and vocals
About the Bidibids:
With lush harmonies, intricate arrangements, and beguiling melodies, the Bidibids explore what it means to play folk music in New Zealand. The Bidibids are Sarah August on banjo and guitar, Simon Carryer on cello-banjo, and Brendan Schenk on mandolin and guitar. The trio came together at the 2020 Wellington Folk Festival, where they were each supposed to be playing in different groups. Since then, the Wellington-based band have become regulars at some of the region’s best venues for folk music, including the Mussel Inn, Moon, and the Wellington Bluegrass Society.
Driven by Sarah’s honest, intimate songwriting and Brendan’s blazing musicianship, the Bidibids balance soulful ballads that will tug your heart-strings with upbeat numbers which will get your toes tapping. Influenced by American bluegrass and folk bands like Watchhouse and Nickel Creek, they’re also inspired by local acts like the Eastern and Marlon Williams who are forging an authentic New Zealand folk tradition. You can listen to the Bidibids' debut EP here: https://open.spotify.com/album/6Q8HW5g0FzDl3VYz44OZU5?si=4gIRmfaRSiOUlgxJnVUbuw.

id: Darren Watson Sings John Hiatt - The Shed-46a Victoria Street, Alicetown, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Darren Watson Sings John Hiatt - The Shed
venue: 46a Victoria Street, Alicetown, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
description:
This will be Darren's first performance in the Wellington region in almost half a decade! Strictly limited tickets so book early to avoid disappointment.
Enjoy an amazing night with legendary blues artist Darren Watson. Darren is a seasoned singer-songwriter and blues musician with over three decades of experience in the music industry. Based in Aotearoa/New Zealand, Darren has built a reputation for his authentic blues sound, combining traditional influences with contemporary themes. His music is characterized by thoughtful lyrics, skilled guitar work, and a voice that carries both grit and soul.
With Darren for this intimate Shed appearance will be stellar double bassist Steve Moodie, and once wunderkind but still wunderful guitarist Chris Armour.
Darren first gained recognition in the 1980s as the leader and frontman of the New Zealand band Chicago Smoke Shop. Since then, he has pursued a successful solo career, releasing a series of well-received albums. His 2020 album, Getting Sober for the End of the World, was widely praised for its sharp social commentary and musical craftsmanship, earning airplay and accolades both locally and internationally. It saw Darren nominated as a finalist for the 2021 Aotearoa Music Award for Best Folk Artist.
Watson's new album 'Darren Watson sings John Hiatt' is due for release in late 2025.

id: Gong Bath at The Lotus Centre 26.07.2025-91 Ruapehu Street, Paraparaumu 5032, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Gong Bath at The Lotus Centre 26.07.2025
venue: 91 Ruapehu Street, Paraparaumu 5032, New Zealand
description:
Nick is a musician and Mindful Somatic therapist based in Wellington and has been putting on gong baths throughout Wellington and more recently in Kapiti. The session has been crafted musically, leaning on deep drones from Paiste gongs and other instruments that harmonize together in layers, rather than loud, crashing strikes of the gong. Nick considers the nervous system throughout, giving you an experience of 'dropping' into deeper brainwave states through the form and gentle introduction.
The sound of the session is more like contemporary ambient music using acoustic instruments than traditional Eastern music, and positive feedback has included: feeling extremely relaxed, to having psychedelic imagery, to processing old memories. You never know what might happen, so its about just being open to the experience.
$35 per person with limited tickets/spaces!

id: Daniel Champagne (Australia) LIVE at Tsunami Lounge | Levin-14 Potts Road, Levin 5571, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Daniel Champagne (Australia) LIVE at Tsunami Lounge | Levin
venue: 14 Potts Road, Levin 5571, New Zealand
description:
PRESENTED BY NIGHTINGALE CONCERTS - JOIN US FOR AN EVENING OF LIVE MUSIC AT IT'S FINEST! 
The young virtuoso recently described as “the finest guitar player of this generation” has spent the past few years selling out shows all over the globe and will be bringing his dynamite live act back to New Zealand in 2025 for a series of intimate regional concerts!
Seated show
Family friendly  
Cheaper $15 tickets for under 18s because live music is for everyone!
BYO (non alcohol) drinks and snacks
October 16, 2025 @ Tsunami Lounge, Levin (NEW LOCATION: 14 Potts Road Levin)
Doors open from 7:00pm / show starts at 7:30pm (9:20pm finish) 
2 x 40 minute sets with an intermission including supper!
Tickets are VERY limited. DON'T miss out!
WHAT THE PRESS SAY..
“The word Prodigy seems to entirely fall short of this soft-spoken young man’s skills, he coaxes sounds and melodies out of his instrument that literally drop jaws.”
The Calgary Herald, CANADA

“Today I saw the future of Folk – Festival goers flocking in the thousands towards the main stage to witness a young musical phenomenon from Australia dish out an absolute show-stopper.” The Firefly Column, USA

“Daniel Champagne is a crossroads. Fusing the strong traditions of Blues, Folk and other roots art with pop showmanship and admirable lyrical ability. I firmly believe that he will become an ambassador for roots music in a time where it desperately needs representation.” The Indie Blender, CANADA

“reinventing roots guitar” Rhythms Magazine, AUSTRALIA“Watching Daniel Champagne perform is a once in a lifetime experience. He is a true prodigy that plays like no one else could possibly play unless they spent at least two lifetimes studying the art.” BW Review, NEW ZEALAND

“Daniel Champagne exudes a natural ease on stage, as he sings poignant lyrics and beautifully crafted melodies that invariably whisk the heart up with grand romanticism. Coupled with an exhilarating guitar talent that transcends mere acoustic playing to replicate a whole band, Champagne is just magical” Themusic.com.au, AUSTRALIA

"You feel as if he just invented the instrument yesterday and was discovering its possibilities afresh” Ted Gioia (American jazz critic and music historian)

id: The Tempests EP Release-62 Bell Street, Featherston 5710, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: The Tempests EP Release
venue: 62 Bell Street, Featherston 5710, New Zealand
description:
The Tempests
Vocalists Jade Eru and Lynley Christoffersen weave vocal magic born from a shared experience and bond that only comes from years of singing together to create a sound greater than the sum of its parts. 
Soulful, sweet harmonies skillfully backed by a band of accomplished yet understated musicians.
Drummer Richard Te One, bassist Miklin Halstead, guitarists Chris Armour and Rob Matthews form the backbone of The Tempests. Drawing from a deep well of musical knowledge and influences, their supportive and tenacious musicianship help to swell the sound of the Tempests and serve the song. 
The Tempests have crafted timeless melodies and emotionally rich songs into vivid aural tapestries.
Hamish Graham.
Hamish has often been found on a baritone guitar with Wellington stalwarts Hobnail, or fronting his own cello-pop ensemble, Milkthistle.
Hamish brings his distinctive take on the world around us with lush and lively approaches to well-crafted songs that follow an arc of experiences and emotions.

id: INTRO TO MUSICAL IMPROV | A POPROX IMPROV COURSE-61/69 Abel Smith Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: INTRO TO MUSICAL IMPROV | A POPROX IMPROV COURSE
venue: 61/69 Abel Smith Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Musical improv can be absolute magic. Whether it's a whole musical show, or single song that bursts out of an emotional scene, music adds so much to our improv.
This course for improvisers will give an introduction to musical improv. We'll cover basic song structures, how to get into a song from a scene, how to support a song through chorus work, and why and when we use music to add to our improv.
Participants should be confident in scene-work and have at least 2 years improv experience. This course will not teach you how to approach scenes and characters, so you should have a solid foundation which you can add to with this new toolbox of musical skills.
The course includes 6 workshops which will run 6:30pm to 8:30pm on Wednesdays from August 6th to September 10th. As it is an intro course, we do not anticipate a showcase for this course.
ABOUT THE TEACHERS
LIA KELLY is a theatre-maker and teacher based in Pōneke. She is an established director, actor, improviser and musician and has been a part of productions across the city over the last 10 years. She directed One Night Band which won 'Most Original Production' at the Wellington Theatre Awards 2023, and performs regularly as both a player and musician for POPROX.
ISAAC THOMAS has been an improviser and improv musician for a decade in Pōneke and Whakatū/Nelson. He's played with Body in Space, Playshop, Poprox and been musical director for musical improv powerhouse The Pāua Ballads. He has worked with almost every major improv company around the city accompanying them through improvised piano, guitar and vocals.
THE STANDY-BY LIST
PopRox firmly believes that improv is for everyone, especially when it comes to sharing skills and knowledge. So we're offering "the stand-by list" for all our workshops in 2025. We'll giveaway any spots remaining a few days before the first workshop of the course, on a first-come-first-serve basis. No need to provide a reason, no questions asked. If the entry fee is a barrier for you to come along, then simply email poproximprov@gmail.com and we'll pop you on the SBL. Everyone on the list will be notified whether there was a place available for them 3 days before the first workshop.

id: Catfish Trifecta presents: The Cuck Chair-17b Allen Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Catfish Trifecta presents: The Cuck Chair
venue: 17b Allen Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
You hate improv? Tell us why… then be forced to watch it.
From the unhinged minds of Wellington’s most insane comedy trio (Mo Munn, Ralph Hilaga, and Joel Luscombe) comes an original improv comedy format that is so boundary-breaking and genre-defining that it made Van Gogh s**t his pants.
What begins as punishment becomes prophecy, as Catfish Trifecta performs relentlessly, defiantly and with far too much commitment, finishing towards an unholy finale nobody asked for.

You won’t be ready, but you’re coming anyway.
Tickets $5
Time and date: 8pm Thursday 31 July 2025
Venue: The Circus Bar, 17b Allen St
Disclaimer: This is an improvised comedy show. Any audience participation is 100% voluntary and consensual. No one will be forced into the Cuck Chair (unless they're really into that).

id: Is it off?-12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Is it off?
venue: 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
An oversharer with a splash of OCD, comedian, improviser and playwright Mo Munn was once called “unhinged” by a reviewer - and now she’s made it her whole personality! In her first solo hour, Mo squishes stand up, experimental and improvised comedy together for a rapid-fire whiplash of a show! Think one woman comedy buffet, packed with chaotic jokes, outlandish stories and a touch of spectacle. Fresh from debuting at the NZ International Comedy Fest and taking home two comedy awards, Is it off? will keep audiences on their toes, delivering a comedy experience more hectic than a high school rave.
“… her show goes off in a very good way. It deserves to travel far and wide, as long as the oven is up for that." - John Smythe, Theatreview
" She jabs and slices at her audience and draws laughs instead of blood.... Thematically it's perfect" -Wellyott, Is it off?

id: Botanical Watercolour on Calf Vellum-101 Glenmore Street, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Botanical Watercolour on Calf Vellum
venue: 101 Glenmore Street, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
'Have you ever wondered what all the fuss is about vellum?

Botanical artist, Lesley Alexander will share her knowledge of painting on vellum.
Used as a writing and painting surface since before the Middle Ages, Lesley loves the luminosity and glow that can be achieved working this traditional way.

You will learn:
what vellum is
how it is prepared
it's uses now and in times past
how to prepare the vellum with pumice powder and
watercolour techniques to work on this very beautiful surface before spending the rest of the time painting a small colourful Pohutukawa leaf.
Ideally you will have some experience using watercolour but that is not essential.

Materials provided: 
A small piece of natural vellum

Materials participants need to bring:
A small piece of natural vellum will be supplied, and some art supplies will be available for you to use, but please bring:
Watercolour paper for practicing techniques - a small A5 piece is all you will need
Notebook or paper for taking notes
A4 piece of tracing paper
Watercolour paints - professional quality is best, but bring what you have making sure they are transparent or semi-transparent pigments
White gouache
Watercolour brushes - you will need small sizes such as #00, #1, #2, #4
HB or H pencil
Putty rubber
Masking tape
Board - A4 to tape the vellum to
Scalpel – with rounded blade
Palette
Soft cloth or kitchen roll
Small water container x 2
Magnifying glass
There may be a chance to buy pieces of vellum at the end of the workshop.

From 15-17 August, The Magnificent Weirdos is teaming up with writers in the early stages of creating new work to present rehearsed readings of these works in progress for the public, followed by audience kōrero with each writer/creator.

All the work is created by writers and devisers with lived experience of disability, neurodivergence, d/Deafness or mental distress.
Each work of approximately 20 minutes will be presented once over the weekend. Each reading will be followed by a 30 minute chat with the writer, facilitated by the director. It's an exciting and creative way to develop new work, both for writers, who receive feedback at an early stage, and for audiences who get to water the seed from which the fruit will eventually grow.
We will also be hosting an industry workshop led by Playmarket, leading a conversation on opportunities, processes and accessibility for new playwrights. Playwrights will need to register for this free workshop which has 20 spaces.
The whole event is NZSL interpreted. Accessible to blind/low vision folks without audio description.
You can check out the program for more details of each play, content notes and pre show information, but here's a quick glance over the weekend. Each event runs for approximately 1 hour.
15 Aug
6 pm- Cryptid Hunters of Aotearoa New Zealand by Rem Wigmore
Tensions rise when a group of friends seek the fabled Fiordland moose.
7.30pm- This is Going to Ruin the Sing-Along by Hamish Boyle
Three artists struggle to let go of the past and are unsure if they even should.
16 Aug
11 am- Playmarket hosts a workshop for writers
a conversation on opportunities, processes and accessibility for new playwrights. Free, registration required.
12.45pm- Rongo's First Day by Rahera Solomon
This wordless play follows a young Māori boy with takiwātanga as he navigates his first day at school.
3pm- Never Tried to Kill the Woman With the Golden Gun by Emma Maguire
The description is in the title! They Never Tried to Kill the Woman With the Golden Gun!
4.30pm- The Eagle Leaves a Scar by Sam Pretious
Ancient myth informs this allegory for our current times.
17 Aug
12.45pm- Forgot the Music by Ethan Rodgers
Two friends wake up in a recording studio with no memory of the night before.
3pm- As the Sun Sets by Tee Wood
A woman shares past secrets with unseen guardians of a graveyard.
4.30pm- Per Second Per Second by Shaun Swain
A time traveller must learn to trust the audience to prevent a time paradox that may/may not have/has/had/is already happened/happens/happening

id: Homicidal Pacifist- Dust Off Your Guillotines-12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Homicidal Pacifist- Dust Off Your Guillotines
venue: 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Three haunted sock puppets leading government. Shit-for-brains liberals peddling ‘both sides’ fucknuggetry as the people march for peace and their governments pour gasoline on fire. And wt actual f is a ‘lesser’ evil? Sameena Zehra is back to explore whether it's time to dust off your guillotines (even for a pacifist, it’s definitely time) with dark comedy & delicious storytelling that will make you gasp and guffaw as you channel your inner homicidal pacifist to pen a culling list of your own.
Following a sold out season at NZ International Comedy Festival earlier this year, Sameena is bringing this show back for one night only during TAHI festival as part of TAHI Encores season.
Content Notes
This show is accessible to Blind or Low Vision folks without audio description.
The venue is fully accessible. 
No loud noises or flashing lights. I will occasionally raise my voice, but will avoid shouting.
Adult, political, and other confrontational content (see title). 
Also... coarse language, because... lalochezia (look it up).
Some direct chat with the audience- however, if you avert your eyes or shake your head, I will not speak directly to you.
Queer friendly.
Sameena Zehra is an award winning comedian, storyteller, actor, writer, director and blues singer/songwriter. She is a political satirist, an intersectional feminist, and a humanist. Her humour is dark and her mind is absurd, equally at home exploring the individual experiences of daily life and the larger issues of the world we live in, creating work that is rooted in the human condition, in holding power to account, and in bringing people together in spaces that are tender and robust. She has performed her solo shows all over the world, including Edinburgh Fringe, Melbourne International Comedy Festival, Brighton Fringe, Adelaide Fringe, The Nordic Fringes, and New Zealand Fringe, where she was nominated for 'Best In Fringe' 2016, and won 'Outstanding Performer' in 2017. Before moving to Aotearoa New Zealand in 2019, Sameena lived and worked in the UK where she has performed at the National Theatre, and has toured internationally with the Royal Shakespeare Company. She performed the critically acclaimed season of her show 'Tea with Terrorists' at Circa Theatre in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, (which was nominated in the ‘Outstanding Performer’  and ‘Best Director’ categories at the Wellington Theatre Awards) before touring it at festivals around Aotearoa.
Here's things people have said about shows Sameena has made...don't take them too seriously, it's just individuals, with individual opinions. You might have different ones (but you'll have to come to the show to find out)
‘Astonishing, and frequently violent... ’ The Independent, UK (That's a particularly good one)
‘Outstanding...a master storyteller’ Rip It Up, Adelaide
'Funny, fiery, brave and true.’ Herald, Scotland
‘Humour in every strand’
‘Left wanting the next chapter’ The Latest, Brighton
‘...an intimate atmosphere with all the warmth, energy and enthusiasm of a full house at the Apollo’
‘Fluency, intensity and vivacity... ’The Age, Melbourne
‘...combines warmth with political passion.’ Scotsgay
‘... smart and sharp... a breath of fresh air... ’ Nicholas Holm, The Post, NZ
‘ ... the wittiest and sassiest lady I’ve ever had the pleasure of watching. Move over Kitty Flanagan.’ Buzzcut, Perth
(Honestly, this one's a bit over the top- Kitty Flanagan is amazing and absolutely not moving over for anyone)

id: The Nerd (by Larry Shue)-166 Muritai Road, Eastbourne, Lower Hutt 5013, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: The Nerd (by Larry Shue)
venue: 166 Muritai Road, Eastbourne, Lower Hutt 5013, New Zealand
description:
NOTE Performances on 10 & 11 July are cancelled and extra performance on 16 July.
The Nerd by Larry Shue
Aspiring architect Willum Cubbert has often told his friends about the debt he owes to Rick Steadman, whom he has never met, but was saved by, after he was seriously wounded in Vietnam. Willum is thrilled when Rick shows up unexpectedly for his 39th birthday, but his delight quickly fades as Rick is a hopeless nerd – a bumbling idiot with no social sense, little emotional intelligence, and even less tact.  Rick moves in and stays on and on, his continued presence among Willum and his friends creates unimaged chaos, until the normally placid Willum can no longer take it and he and his friends devise an insane plan to finally get Rick to leave.
Don’t miss this hilarious farce that ran on Broadway for 441 performances and went on to be performed the world over.
Performance dates: 12 & 16-19 July 2025, 7.30pm, Muritai School Hall, Eastbourne

id: Messiah-71 Woburn Road, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Messiah
venue: 71 Woburn Road, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
description:
Experience the uplifting power of Handel’s Messiah this winter with a special afternoon performance at 3pm on Saturday, 19 July 2025, at St James' Anglican Church, Lower Hutt. 
This unique collaboration brings together two of Wellington’s most respected choirs: the Festival Singers, directed by Ingrid Schoenfeld, and the St Mary of the Angels Choir, directed by William McElwee. 
Acclaimed organist Jonathan Berkahn will accompany the performance, adding his signature depth and colour to the work’s stirring arias and choruses.
Ingrid Schoenfeld, a concert pianist, has led the Festival Singers since 2019, earning praise for her warm, engaging conducting style and commitment to musical excellence. 
William McElwee, Director of Music at St Mary of the Angels, is a multifaceted musician known for drawing outstanding vocalism from his choirs and stretching them musically. 
Jonathan Berkahn, a seasoned performer and educator with a PhD in musicology, brings a wealth of experience as an accompanist, soloist, and chamber musician, enriching the performance with his expertise.
While traditionally associated with Christmas and Easter, this mid-winter performance of Messiah offers a refreshing opportunity to experience its radiant choruses and sparkling solos in a new light. 
The comfortable setting and lovely acoustics of St James' Anglican Church make it an ideal venue for a winter afternoon concert – a popular choice during the colder months. 
Featuring talented soloists from both choirs, this concert promises to be a heart-warming highlight of the season.

id: Wellington Leaders Day-22 Tennyson Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Wellington Leaders Day
venue: 22 Tennyson Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Laidlaw Centre for Church Leadership exists to love and serve the Church of Aotearoa New Zealand by providing her leaders with the tools, support, and guidance they need to flourish. 
Join us for a one day conference as we gather with leaders from across the region to connect, be inspired and encouraged, and discuss issues relevant to the Church in Aotearoa. The event runs from 9am to 2:30pm. Morning tea and lunch is included.
Theme: Stewarding Renewal
Our 2025 Leaders Days explore emerging reports across New Zealand and the globe of increasing openness to faith in Christ, and in some cases significant growth in church attendance and baptisms, led by younger generations; and how church leaders might respond.
"In churches across society something amazing is happening, challenging long held predictions about the future of Christianity in the twenty-first century. Where we once saw ageing congregations and a steady decline in attendance, we now see dramatic growth, led by the young. Where we once saw apathy or even hostility to Christianity and the Bible we see increased openness." - Bible Society UK
In the United States a similar trend is emerging:
"Undeniably there is renewed interest in Jesus," says David Kinnaman, CEO of Barna. "This is the clearest trend we've seen in more than a decade pointing to spiritual renewal — and it's the first time Barna has recorded such spiritual interest being led by younger generations." - Barna Group, USA
On Easter Sunday in New Zealand, St Patricks Cathedral in Auckland baptized 350 people. Testimonies are emerging from churches across Aotearoa of an openness to faith, responses from people previously not interested in church, and a curiosity about Christ and Christianity among non-believers, particularly young people.
As church and Christian leaders in Aotearoa New Zealand, how might we respond in our contexts?
How could we participate in what the Spirit is doing? What does this mean for sustainability of people and programmes, and for our discipleship teams? How can we discern the best response to the opportunities presented by this context? How can we stir hunger for renewal in our time and place, without unhealthy comparison?
We are gathering leaders from across Aotearoa in four locations for a one day conference to discuss these questions. There will be opportunity to hear testimonies of renewal happening in churches in Aotearoa, and share your thoughts with other leaders as we gather — we pray you will walk away encouraged, inspired, and with fresh vision for the days ahead.
We hope to see you there!
Programme:
Session One: Emerging Renewal
More and more, stories are emerging of green shoots in surprising places: tales of people without church backgrounds turning up at church quite unexpectedly, more frequent conversations with those curious about Jesus, dramatic spiritual encounters that we could never have facilitated. There is a sense that the upheaval of Covid, global political shifts, and financial uncertainty in recent years has shifted something: the fragmentation and failure of secularism and new atheism was perhaps preparing the ground. It seems like something is happening - a quiet renewal.
What does this mean for the communities we lead? How can we, as leaders, steward these firstfruits of renewal? How can we lean in to what the Spirit is doing in our own contexts?
Session Two: Stories of Renewal
In this panel discussion, local pastors and leaders share stories of how they are seeing that God has been moving — stirring renewal and hope, unexpected shifts in discipleship and salvations, and how they are responding.
Session Three: Renewal and Fruitfulness
Time and time again throughout history, renewal has come through small communities making radical commitments to the way of Jesus. What can renewal movements throughout history teach us about renewal in our own moment? What helps? What doesn't? What does it look like to be faithful in our time and place?
Session Four: Renewal Conversations
What does it look like to steward renewal in our churches? This session focuses on practical responses to renewal and discussion around how the Church in Aotearoa can partner with what the Spirit is doing.
Speakers:
Sam Harvey, 24-7 Prayer New Zealand
Sam Harvey is the founding and Lead Pastor of Bay Vineyard Church and the National Coordinator for 24-7 Prayer NZ. He has been in full-time ministry since graduating from BCNZ (now Laidlaw) in 2003. He is passionate about coming alongside church leaders to encourage strong prayer cultures in churches. His 24-7 role gives him a front row seat to a lot of what God is doing among our churches. Sam is married to Jenn and they have three lively sons. Sam loves good food, good music and good waves. We are excited to have him with us!
Roshan Allpress, Laidlaw College
Dr Roshan Allpress has led Laidlaw College as National Principal/Chief Executive since 2017. He holds History degrees from Canterbury and Oxford, focusing on religious reform, philanthropy, and theology’s social impact. He co-founded the Compass (now Venn) Foundation and has extensive experience in non-profit leadership. Raised in Ōtautahi Christchurch, he and his wife Lottie have three children and now live in Auckland.
Local Panels
In each location we will be joined by local pastors and leaders sharing experiences of renewal from their contexts. More information coming soon!

id: Urinetown: The Musical-38A Duncan Street, Tawa, Wellington 5028, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Urinetown: The Musical
venue: 38A Duncan Street, Tawa, Wellington 5028, New Zealand
description:
Urinetown: The Musical, is... well it's a musical that takes place in a dystopian setting where, due to an immense drought, its townsfolk have to pay fees in order to pee, controlled by a money-hungry corporation. But we wouldn't want to overload you with too much exposition, huh?
And before you scoff at its oddities, don't worry, Urinetown's already laughing at itself with jokes like "Wee-wee never fail."  But beyond its potty humour and absurd premise, Urinetown: The Musical, unveils itself with its political messages that also satirises the musical genre. From a gospel number to a climax that references Les Misérables, it dazzles at the same time as it depresses.
So-- come and watch. If not for the comedic choruses, then for the capitalistic commentary. The musical reminds us, as much as we can laugh at the central conceit of the show, we're not so far from the songs it's singing. 
Original music and lyrics by Mark Hollmann and Greg Kotis (2001); performed by Tawa College."

id: Tales of the Unexpected - WELLINGTON-11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Tales of the Unexpected - WELLINGTON
venue: 11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Royal Society Te Apārangi are delighted to present the 2024 Rutherford Medal winner in a special public talk.  Don’t miss this opportunity to hear from one of New Zealand’s leading researchers - this promises to be a fascinating and thought-provoking evening. 
Professor Richard Beasley CNZM FRSNZ, the 2024 Rutherford Medal winner, will highlight ten influential research programmes that have challenged long-held clinical assumptions, advanced medical knowledge, and directly influenced patient care:
Should fever be treated?
What is the optimal amount of oxygen for critically ill patients?
Are party pills safe, and do they affect driving performance?
Does smoking cannabis cause lung cancer?
Is sitting for long periods at work or during recreation a risk factor for blood clots?
Should preservatives be included in asthma nebuliser solutions?
Is ‘watchful waiting’ preferable to surgery for a collapsed lung?
What are the underlying disease processes of asthma?
What was the cause of the epidemic of asthma deaths in New Zealand?
Are adult asthma treatments suitable for children?
The answers to many of these research questions were unexpected. The research raises significant regulatory and legal issues. It also exposes the limited evidence of the benefit and safety of many fundamental approaches to the clinical management of common disorders, and the gaps in knowledge, particularly in children.
Join us for this fascinating presentation that will illustrate the unpredictable nature of research and its influence to reshape our understanding.
Biography
Professor Richard Beasley, renown academic, physician, and researcher, is the founder and director of the Medical Research Institute of New Zealand (MRINZ). Richard is committed to challenging medical dogma and increasing knowledge through undertaking high quality clinical research which has the real potential to change clinical practice and reduce the burden of disease in Aotearoa New Zealand and globally.
Alongside his role at the MRINZ, Richard is a physician at Wellington Regional Hospital, and maintains close academic links through his professorial appointments at the University of Southampton, UK, Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, and the University of Otago. Richard was Deputy Chair of the Health Research Council of New Zealand from 2010 to 2016 and has had a longstanding medical advisory role with the Asthma and Respiratory Foundation of New Zealand, chairing the adolescent and adult asthma guidelines group. He is dedicated to workforce training, having supervised and mentored hundreds of medical research fellows over the last three decades, many of whom obtained postgraduate MD and PhD degrees and now hold prominent academic and clinical positions in Aotearoa New Zealand and around the world.
Richard is one of New Zealand’s most experienced clinician researchers, with over 780 publications, including many high impact publications in the Lancet and the New England Journal of Medicine. Richard was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit for services to medical research in 2008; elected a Fellow of the Royal Society Te Apārangi of New Zealand in 2015; awarded the Sir Charles Hercus Medal in 2016 in recognition of the impact of his research, the Beaven Medal in 2019 in recognition of his translational research, and was awarded the Rutherford Medal by the Royal Society Te Apārangi in 2024 for revolutionising the treatment of asthma worldwide.
Seats are limited, so book early to avoid missing out.

Supported by Royal Society Te Apārangi and the Medical Research Institute of New Zealand (MRINZ)

id: FLINT Wellington: Fintech Futures - From Ideas to Impact-1 Whitmore Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: FLINT Wellington: Fintech Futures - From Ideas to Impact
venue: 1 Whitmore Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Join us on July 24th for an electrifying FLINT Fintech panel event that promises to be a game-changer! We're bringing together some of the brightest minds in the industry to discuss the future of financial technology and innovation, specifically aimed at young, aspiring fintech enthusiasts.
Our stellar lineup includes:
Asantha Wijeyeratne, the dynamic CEO and co-founder of Paysource, who’s revolutionizing the way we think about payroll.
Emma Geard, a savvy senior associate from MinterEllisonRuddWatts, with a sharp focus on payments, technology and its legal implications.
Adiraj Gupta is a seasoned fintech entrepreneur across NZ and the US
The visionary GM Startups and Tech Sector at Creative HQ, Colm Kearny, leading the charge in startups from Fintech to climate.
This event is perfect for young people eager to dive into the world of fintech startups. You'll hear about the exciting innovations, the challenges faced, the obstacles to watch out for, and gain the confidence to just go for it. Don't miss this opportunity to gain insights, network with industry leaders, and be part of the conversation shaping the future of fintech. See you there!
We are incredibly thankful to the team at MinterEllisonRuddWatts for their hosting and partnership for this event.
Grab your ticket today! It's FREE for FLINT members (see below how to join). 
We can't wait to welcome you to this fun and interactive session. 
__________________________________
Asantha has over 20 years’ experience of unparalleled focus on helping small businesses navigate the difficult landscape of effective payroll. His formal background in accounting, combined with his ‘people first’ attitude, has seen him successfully build a number of businesses into market leadership positions. Asantha’s obsession is the small business sector, with a technology and customer service focus. He loves seeing someone with determination and passion turn an idea into a business that supports them, their families and the wider community. He gets a lot of enjoyment from making tech work to help business owners succeed. In recognition of his contribution to business and the community, he was awarded a Queen's Service Medal (QSM) in the New Year’s honours list in 2013 and was a finalist in Ernst & Young’s 2021 Entrepreneur of the Year.
Colm is GM of Startups and Tech Sector at Creative HQ, Wellington’s basecamp for bold ideas and entrepreneurial thinking. He leads the team behind the Fintech Lab Accelerator, supporting early-stage fintech founders to validate, grow and scale their ventures – helping turn ambitious ideas into real-world impact.
Creative HQ’s work spans startup acceleration, innovation training, and ecosystem development – with fintech a fast-growing focus. Colm will share insights from the frontline of Aotearoa’s startup scene and spotlight upcoming opportunities for those looking to shape the future of financial services.
Emma is a banking and finance lawyer at MinterEllisonRuddWatts with broad regulatory and advisory experience and particular expertise in payment systems and prudential regulation of banks, non-bank deposit takers and financial markets infrastructure. She has advised financial institutions and financial industry bodies on regulatory change, engaging with the legislative process, compliance and enforcement matters .
Adiraj Gupta is a seasoned fintech entrepreneur across NZ and the US, with ventures in cross-border payments, crypto, and personal finance. His latest venture, Sendd, helps small businesses launch online stores in seconds. He’s Entrepreneur in Residence at The Atom and a tireless connector in Wellington’s startup community
Grab your ticket today! It's FREE for FLINT members (see below how to join). 
We can't wait to welcome you to this fun and interactive session. 
__________________________________
About FLINT
If you’re in the early stages of your digital career and you’re interested in digital technologies, come join the FLINT programme in your local city. We host events, webinars, podcasts and social catch ups that offer valuable networking, learning and growth opportunities. 
Find out more here: Flint - TUANZ

id: WellyForge#2, 30th July 2025-118 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: WellyForge#2, 30th July 2025
venue: 118 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Join us to help progress Wellington by bringing together science, tech & investors from across the city into an informal, fun and informative meet-up. The goal of the event is that you learn something new, meet someone new, have fun and we all start forging new paths ahead for Wellington.
The July event will have two main talks & Q/A from Wellington-based:
Neil Butler, proud Wellingtonian, founder and Chair of Optimation who won the Spark Best Hi-Tech Product for the Public Good at the 2025 NZ Hi-Tech awards.

id: Te ORA Hui-ā-Tau & Scientific Conference 2025-41 Te Rauparaha Street, Ōtaki 5512, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Te ORA Hui-ā-Tau & Scientific Conference 2025
venue: 41 Te Rauparaha Street, Ōtaki 5512, New Zealand
description:
Nau mai, haere mai.

Te ORA invites our members, whānau, partners, and supporters to come together for Hui-ā-Tau 2025, held at Te Wānanga o Raukawa in Ōtaki, a place of cultural strength, learning, and connection.

Hokia ki ō maunga kia pūrea e koe ngā hau a Tāwhirimātea
Return to your mountain to be cleansed by the winds of Tāwhirimātea

As Māori Medical Practitioners we are often exposed to unique pressures and responsibilities not only within our workplace, but also within our whānau and the communities we serve. For that reason, an important way of remaining grounded is to return to our maunga, our awa, and whenua to be refuelled and replenished for the mahi ahead of us.

Over four days, we’ll reflect on our progress, celebrate our people, and explore what it means to thrive as Māori in medicine. This gathering is an opportunity to socialise, connect, learn, and contribute to the future of Māori health in an uplifting space.

The programme includes:
Te Rā Tūhura: A careers expo for tauira and aspiring Māori health professionals
Annual General Meeting (financial members only) & Wānanga
Scientific Conference (2 days): Keynotes, abstract presentations, and panel discussions
Te ORA Awards Dinner: A night to celebrate leadership, service, and achievement across our community
Please Note:
An Awards Dinner ticket is included for the following registration types:
– Full Conference Registration (all member types)
– PGY1/PGY2 Junior Doctors
– Tauira (Students)
– Non-Members
– Sponsors
If you are bringing whānau or guests to the Awards Dinner, their tickets will need to be purchased separately.
Tamariki Programme
We’re working to create a safe and engaging tamariki programme during Hui-ā-Tau 2025, depending on interest and age ranges.
If you're planning to bring tamariki, please complete the tamariki registration for each individual so we can understand numbers, ages, and needs. This will help us finalise the programme and ensure appropriate support is in place.
Details will be confirmed closer to the event.
Accommodation On-Site at Te Wānanga o Raukawa
We have a limited number of on-site beds available at Te Wānanga o Raukawa.

If you're interested in staying on-site during Hui-ā-Tau, please let us know at checkout. Spaces are limited and will be allocated based on interest and availability.
Important – Support for Tauira
Tauira who require support with travel to Hui-ā-Tau must complete their registration no later than Thursday 29 August 2025.
After this date, Te ORA will not be able to guarantee support for travel.

Whether you’re a student, doctor, or supporter, this is your invitation to be part of Te ORA's biggest event of the year.

id: L'Dor V'Dor 2025 - “SEARCHING FOR IDENTITY”-80 Webb Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: L'Dor V'Dor 2025 - “SEARCHING FOR IDENTITY”
venue: 80 Webb Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
“SEARCHING FOR IDENTITY”
By Claire Bruell
Design & Production by Mike Reganon
"This is your history, these are your stories, my gift to you." These are the last words in Claire Bruell's four-book series to future generations - her "five beautiful grandchildren", Simon, Sofia, Lily, Nate, and Isaac.
But more than a gift to her grandchildren, these books spell out the trauma Jews have faced over millennia and, through her resolute and gently probing of the Bruell and Briess family trees over four generations, she exemplifies the lives of so many. Jews around the world will identify with the tragedies and joys, the uplifting and the horror, the sheer delight and abject gloom.
Carefully moulded over four books, Claire describes these stages and reveals the lives of her ancestors as they grow and achieve success, have wonderful families, meet catastrophe, are split asunder, murdered by Nazis, and finally regather the remnants to rebuild - a story so familiar to Jews who have only sought peaceful coexistence for centuries.
Claire will describe aspects of the process of creating that content from age 32 through to today, and with Mike, will speak about some of the features of working together and the exquisite joy of laying it all out on paper.
Claire Bruell
Claire is a historian particularly interested in 19th-century Europe and the Holocaust. Her interests span history, genealogy, reading, collecting curios and ex libris, and from time to time she speaks and writes on many of these subjects. She has been a Justice of the Peace for 30 years and the coordinator of an oral history project in Auckland for almost as long. Her days are focused on family and community.
Mike Reganon
Mike is a retired teacher, journalist, editor, designer, and publisher. He has dabbled in pottery, sculpture, printing, oil painting, and renovating the family home, a lifetime occupation. Today, he continues his clay creations by joining a local pottery group and has begun learning Yiddish using Duolingo. As those skills improve, he hopes to find others keen to practice the mamaloshen, but right now he’s farshmakht.
Important Update
To ensure the continued delivery of our high-quality speaker series, we've transitioned to a paid model. Your support is crucial in maintaining the excellence of our events and speakers. Unlock invaluable insights at our upcoming L'Dor V'Dor single session for just $10*. If you are a Holocaust Centre member, you’ll enjoy an exclusive 30% discount, paying only $7*. 
*GST & booking fee are additional. 
To check your membership status, contact operations@holocaustcentre.org.nz or sign up HERE.

id: Women of Pōneke August 2025 Event-70 Molesworth Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix

venue: 70 Molesworth Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Welcome Meg Williams: living with creativity, awe and imagination

We’re thrilled to officially introduce Meg Williams, CEO of World of WearableArt, as our speaker for the next Women of Pōneke signature event on the 7th of August at The National Library.

Meg is an internationally acclaimed leader in creativity and live events. Over two decades she has worked with artists from around the world and brought major festivals and events to audiences in Aotearoa New Zealand, Australia and the U.K.

This is an extra special time for us to hear from Meg as WOW celebrates 20 years in Pōneke. The uplifting 2025 WOW Show: RISE, is set in an imaginary city illuminated with the creative spirit, and offers us the chance to “ignite what lies within”.

Join us to hear Meg share how she has discovered the power of awe including:
• Goosebump moments from her life in the arts and at WOW
• The power of creativity in leadership and wellbeing
• How we can awaken wonder in our own lives and the communities we walk in

Meg will inspire your imagination and consider how to unleash your passions, whatever they may be and however hidden they may feel.
✨Tickets are now live — come break the winter blues with a night of imagination, inspiration and connection.
Get your tickets now! 
Numbers are limited due to space, so we recommend you get in and quick! We are limited to 180 only. 
We will be serving wine, beer and amazing non-alcoholic drinks, inclusive in the ticket price. Platters will also be shared throughout the evening. 
So grab your ticket now and share with at least one amazing woman (and/or ally) in your life.
To cover our costs, we are charging for this event. We know that things are tough at the moment for many, so if this is a barrier for you to attend, please contact us and we will do everything to support you to attend. 
Help a woman in need
If you wish to support someone else who may have a financial barrier, please buy one of the "Buy-One, Give-One" tickets, so we can support more of the amazing women of Pōneke to attend.
Get in quick!
Tickets for previous events have sold out fast. For this event we are capped at 180 people attending and we will be updating our social media channels on the progress of the ticket sales, so get your tickets quick.  
Accessibility
The National Library is fully accessible. If you are not able to use the steps on Molesworth Street, you will be able to access the venue via the lift off Aitken Street. There will be staff at the door to be able to support and guide you to the venue space.
A bit about us 
Me.We.Pōneke is our signature quarterly event designed to inspire, connect and raise the voices of our wonderful community of Wellington women, and people who identify as women. 
We believe that magic happens when women come together. We’ve seen it. We’ve felt it. And we want to create more of it with regular events that are open, welcoming, supportive and empowering for the women of Wellington.
Come along, bring a friend and join us as we continue to raise the voices of Wellington women and invite you all to be part of Me We Pōneke.
You can join our mailing list from our brand new website, thanks to our amazing partner Springload. Check it out here and make sure you sign up to our mailing list: https://www.womenofponeke.org....
We are also on Insta! Follow us here: https://www.instagram.com/wome…

id: Building a More Secure Future in a Changing Climate: How the UK Connects Climate, Growth and Security-33 Bunny Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Building a More Secure Future in a Changing Climate: How the UK Connects Climate, Growth and Security
venue: 33 Bunny Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
NZIIA Wellington Branch is delighted to welcome members and guests to an upcoming event "Building a More Resilient Future in a Changing Climate: How the UK Connects Climate, Growth and Security"

This event will bring together the Deputy British High Commissioner to New Zealand John Pearson, and the Chief Operating Officer of Octopus Energy NZ, Margaret Cooney for a fascinating event on how the UK approaches the nexus between climate change, security and economic growth.
John Pearson will cover his personal experiences with these issues throughout his career and the UK's modern approach to these global challenges. He will cover how the UK has put climate, nature, and clean energy at the core of domestic and international policy priorities and integrated it into key strategies like the recently released industrial strategy and security strategy. This will outline the journey the UK has been on to more than halves its emissions since 1990, while significantly growing the economy and outlining the path ahead.
Margaret Cooney will discuss her thoughts on clean energy transition, technology and security and talk about what Octopus Energy has done in the UK and their goals in New Zealand. Octopus Energy is a global clean energy tech business headquartered in Great Britain, driving the affordable, green energy system of the future across 18 countries with cutting edge energy products now provided to 7.7 million households globally.
Following short keynotes from John Pearson and Margaret Cooney there will be fireside chat and opportunity for Q&A from the audience.

At the conclusion of the Q&A there will be a networking reception for all attendees kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.

EVENT DETAILS

Date/Time: Tuesday 29 July, 5:30-7:45pm

Venue: RHLT1, Pipitea Campus, Victoria University of Wellington

Doors Open: 5:05pm Q&A will be open to attendees.




TERMS AND CONDITIONS

-Registrations are required to attend this event. No walk ups allowed. Non members can attend by paying the registration fee.

-Should you have not renewed your NZIIA  membership please do so prior to registering for this event.

-One ticket per person. Each ticket must contain your full first and surname, email address and phone number that matches your ID. 

-If, after registering, you are unable to attend the event please have the courtesy to cancel your ticket to ensure other people are able to attend. A waitlist will operate.

-In keeping with NZIIA practice, unauthorised recording of this event (either audio or video) is not permitted. Members and guests are reminded to adhere to the NZIIA Code of Conduct.


BIOGRAPHIES OF OUR SPEAKERS

Deputy British High Commissioner to New Zealand
John Pearson
In the early 2000’s John was the first in the UK to publish on the climate security nexus and helped to inform the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) at the time. Since then he’s integrated a sustainability focus into his work as a diplomat from helping to protect the Amazon while posted in Brazil, leading the UK’s South East Asia climate network, to supporting Laos’s transition to renewables while Ambassador there.

Chief Operating Officer (Country Head), Octopus Energy NZ
Margaret Cooney

Margaret Cooney is the Chief Operating Officer of Octopus Energy New Zealand, a role she's held since June 2020. She spearheads the company's New Zealand operations, focusing on energy sector innovation. Margaret previously led Powershop New Zealand and has held various roles in energy and technology companies in the UK, US, and New Zealand. With deep expertise in energy market regulation and innovation, she also contributes to an Electricity Authority advisory group. Margaret is dedicated to using technology for more affordable and sustainable energy and fostering a competitive New Zealand energy market. She holds Law and Economics degrees from the University of Canterbury and also studied at the University of California, Berkeley.

id: Meet the Seaweeds: After-work seaweed info session with Love Rimurimu-2/57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Meet the Seaweeds: After-work seaweed info session with Love Rimurimu
venue: 2/57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
description:
Curious about our native rimurimu? 
Have a go at identifying some of our local seaweed species at this hands on, after work seaweed session (we’ll be bringing the ocean to you from the comfort of 2/57!). You can find out more about the Love Rimurimu project, and meet the team working to restore the seaweed of Wellington's harbour. 
What’s Love Rimurimu? Imagine the waters of Wellington sustaining a healthy and vibrant ocean forest; able to absorb more carbon than trees, improving water quality and providing habitat for thousands of marine creatures. Regenerating our seaweed forests is a way to make this a reality - and it’s what this project is all about.
Interested in volunteering with Mountains to Sea Wellington? Come along and we can have a chat about opportunities available- our volunteers help us on land and in the water, we'd love for you to join us! 
Seaweed Series: This event is part of a series of events introducing folks to the seaweeds/rimurimu of Wellington. No previous knowledge or experience is necessary to take part in these events, just a bit of seaweed curiosity!
If you want to leave with one of our beautiful waterproof underwater guides these can be bought for $15 on the day, or download for free on our resources page.
Learn more about Love Rimurimu: www.loverimurimu.org/background

id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Treasures from the Gully (Aug 2025)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Treasures from the Gully (Aug 2025)
venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
Treasures from the Gully

Tour through a very atmospheric part of the cemetery, with an eclectic mix of stories on an artist, photographer, hat manufacturer, prison reformer and many more! Come and enjoy the beauty of one of the most mystical places in the Cemetery with entertaining stories along the way.
The tour will mostly keep to pathways but some areas are potentially uneven underfoot. A moderate level of fitness is required.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by midday by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
The tour is approximately 1.5 hours long
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Hangman's Noose Tour (Sept 2025)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Hangman's Noose Tour (Sept 2025)
venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
Hangman's Noose Tour
In total, 85 people have been executed for crime in New Zealand with the first in 1842 and the last in 1957. Seventeen of those men were executed in Wellington and 11 are buried in Karori Cemetery.  This walking tour will visit some of their graves to account their crimes, trials and convictions. It will also visit the plots of some of the victims.

The graves are unmarked and placed in remote and disparate locations making this a tour about 2.5 hours long. The route is 2.5km and requires reasonable physical fitness due to the steep terrain and unsealed paths in places.
The tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions and so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

id: Friends of Karori Cemetery - Evening Tour (Aug 2025)-15 Rosehaugh Avenue, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
name: Friends of Karori Cemetery - Evening Tour (Aug 2025)
venue: 15 Rosehaugh Avenue, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
description:
Evening Tour
Would you like to join us and explore the beauty of Karori Cemetery in the evening?
This tour is for anyone who would like to see the Cemetery through a different lens, as the landscape settles in from dusk to darkness. On this walk you'll be accompanied by two guides who will take you on a wander through some of the most magical parts of the cemetery, with a story or two of early Wellingtonians along the route. We might even spy a Ruru/Morepork or two! The tour does not have any scary themes. There are points on the tour where we may pause and turn off our torches to enjoy the landscape in the darkness.
The tour is of approximately 1.5 hours duration and starts and finishes at the Main Chapel on Rosehaugh Avenue, where there is plenty of easy parking.
Each attendee needs to bring their own torch that they can comfortably carry for the duration. No head torches please for the comfort of your fellow walkers.
The route mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness. Surefootedness is required. This tour involves approximately 2km of walking, with some slow paced but uphill stints.
The tour is not suited for children under the age of 12 or unaccompanied minors. There are no toilets on the route.

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee).
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

Ros Rice - Executive Officer, Community Networks Aotearoa
Barry Baker - NFP and Membership organisations Specialist at Grant Thornton New Zealand
Sadly, this is the last CNA Members’ Hui without a registration fee. As finances tighten, this will be the last FREE Hui for CNA. In the past we've been in a unique position to value our members by providing the Hui for free. 2027 will see the introduction of a registration fee.
🎂 WE’RE 50! 🎂
CNA started life as NZCOSS, which was formed as a national social service umbrella organisation on 10th November 1975 by signed order from the Minister of Social Welfare, Norman King, under the Department of Social Welfare Act 1971.
Since then, we’ve changed our name but continued to provide substantial resources, reports, and representation to the sector and at the government level.
We’ve taken on banks, the State of the Sector Report, Select Committees, and more in order to lessen pain points and provide easier ways forward.
Come celebrate with us at our Members’ Hui – meet some old faces, and some even older faces. A blast from the past as we start our next half century. Time for cake and some bubbles.
Need financial help to attend our LAST FREE Hui?
CNA has a Membership Support Fund that can help. Specifically aimed at Tier 4 and 3 members, please contact Ros at eo@communitynetworksaotearoa.org.nz for more details. Applications close Saturday 31st of May.
Current financial members and guests of CNA are able to attend this event.
